The malts are very thick combined with the yeast, but when cold it doesnt hit that hard. Very nice, I enjoy the belgian yeast a lot here.

a between 2000-2002 vintage @ kulminator 
head: creamy , thin 
colour: red/brown 
smell: bit sour, geueze like, corky, red cabernet wine, bit bourgogne wine acidity , wood resin , oaky 
taste: herby/oaky start, alcohol, verry bitter woody taste, cask, calvados, nuty, extreme taste , dry end , grassy aftertaste , very very very good vintage !!!

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Poured a dark amber with a beige head.  This was very dry with lots of carbonation.  Some sweet tones and vegetable earthiness.  Oak and dark fruits that played like raisins.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2011 750ml bottle shared at a tasting.
Appearance : Hazy dark amber with a small  head.

Aroma : Lots of spices with nice yeast. 

Taste :  Spices with light yeast. Finish dry with spices. A bit mineral.

Overall : This was good but a bit boring I think. I dont know why, maybe it was a bad timing. 

750ml bottle from IPB. 
Appearance : Hazy amber. Light lacing.

Aroma : Great yeast with nice light caramel. A bit mineral. Light bananas.

Taste : Nice yeast with light caramel and some fruits. Quite yeasty. Strong carbonation. Dry finish with light caramel. Great bananas on the finish. 

Overall : Nice surprise. Much better than the first time I tried it. Really enjoyable bananas and caramel. Nice yeast too. Im still not sure Im a fan of this type of beer. Carbonation felt a bit too intense. I also dont think its worth the price tag. Aroma 6 to 7, Taste 6 to 8. Overall 3.5 to 3.8
March 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Frothy beer! Creamy and quite a light palate. Nice dark malts - never too bitter or roasty. Easy to drink but packs a wallop!

Bottle @ glouglou christmas party. Nice looking dark pour with a thick frothy head. Aroma is quite winey, spicy yeast, grapes and chocolate. Flavor is quite chocolaty, sweet, some dark fruit as well. Palate is of course the high point of this beer with the champagne like effervescence and subtle alcohol warmth. Very nice celebratory beer.

Dark caramel brown, this beer is 90% head in a glass if you arent careful.  Aroma is sweet cider, and not in a defect kind of way, either.  Taste is richly apple, with background of darker bready + fruity notes and extreme carbonation scrubs away flavors quickly.  $26/750

Bottle.Best before 2008. Delish! Pours a a deep dark mahogany red with a nice foamy tan head. Dark malts and grapey and chocolate. rish with a very creamy carbomation.. almost felt like nitro. very enjoyable bottle share.
The nose is tight with a slight cocoa aroma. The palate is fruity with cocoa in the background. This beer is tremendous.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a nice thick beige head. Arom and flavour of plu, brown sugar, yeast, spice, dried fruit, caramel and chocolate.

Deep slightly hazy brown pour.  The nose has a lot of plum and pruney fruitiness over a fairly sherryish character.  Moderate cocoa and a touch of soft spiciness as well.  Quite dry with a little bit of toasted malt.  There is a kiss of spiciness as well with a kiss of soft oaky character.  Quite vineous with a nice rich combination of yeasty dryness and an almost flinty finish.  Despite that, there is a bit of continued sweetness mid-palate and a little bit of mintiness.  Its definitely seen fresher days but its still quite nice.  Lightly fruity and spicy  even at this age, its pretty nice stuff.

Reviewed from notes.  Tasted from 750mL bottle.  Pours dark brown amber with a thick tan head that sticks around for a long time.  The nose is dark burnt sugar, with sume dusty earthiness, plum, date, molasses, and maple.  The flavor is very fruity with date, plum, molasses, vanilla, raisin, dark malt, and milk chocolate.  The body is full with very lively carbonation and a long, hot sugary finish.  This beer is awesome and complex.

bottle bb 6/30/2008 consumed 6/27/2010.

walnut stained dark brown colored pour with a soft foamy tan head. the cap sticks around for a while.

yeasty nose with notes of brown sugar, roasty grain, cocoa, prunes, apple-like fruitiness and spice.

the flavor is the same only not as sweet as it smells. woody savory yeast lingers in the aftertaste along with cocoa.

medium body, crisp, fun texture and really easy to drink. 8/4/8/4/17/4.1

Pours dark brown with a thick creamy white head that fades the a thin persistent head. Aroma is a rich sweet burnt caramel with elements of figs and raisin. On the tongue it is full bodied and effervesent. The taste is very rich sweet caramel with the alcohol flavors playing second string. The finish a dry. Very enjoyable. A very special beer.
Pours a reddish brown color with an off-white foam head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit and caramel.  Sweet start, malty.  Bitter finish.  Velvety chocolate end.

Wow - this is a strong beer! The aroma is sweet and malty and notes of raisins. The amber color is completely freckled with sediment throughout the entire brew. The flavor of aged malts settles late with pure raisins and figs shining through clearly.

Bottle. Aroma of plums, malt and fresh wood. Dark redbrown colour with beige head. Flavour of wood, nuts, plums, raisins and portwine. Finish is a bit dry despite the sweet and spicy flavour. Very delicate.

Bottle shared with the local beerfans. Poured murky, deep ruby with a small, lacing head. Dark fruits, raisin, sour cherry, vanilla are the most obvious in the aroma. Sweet as syrup, with a fruity aftertaste. Dry, light hoppy finish. Light body, flat. No sign of the high alcohol content, this beer is very easy on the palate. Smooth, easily drinkable.

Bottle says bbe 30 June 08. In any event, good beer. Bottle gave a good pop to the cork. Poured with a nice tan head which quickly subsided and a tiny bit of lace. Color is a hazy amber brown. Aroma is malty, yeasty, vineous. Flavor is typical dark Belgian and like aroma. Body seems a bit thin but high carbonation makes up for it. Boozy finish and fairly short.
Rock sugar and yeast on the nose. Intense alcoholic sweetness, maltiness and slight hint of balsamic flavor. Dark and smooth, but flavor is too muted to match properly. Slightly slimy.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32. Pours a darkish red/brown. Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol. Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit. Also has strong hints of spice and orange.

Bottle 2 years past its "drink by" date. Beautiful orange-brown color with lots of champagne-like bubbles and a fine, thin, head. Hugely fragrant--filled the room--with dried fruits, plums, caramel, spice. Great. Amazingly rich, chewy flavor of dried raisins and figs, fresh plums, minerals, spicy, with a touch of sour and big alcohol to balance (plus a touch of hops). Super chewy, bubbly, and rich yet somehow light bodied. Simply wonderful.  One of the best Ive had--going straight out to get a fresh one to see how it compares.

Bottled 750ml. -from www.beershop.hr 
Dark brown coloured, medium sized pale brown head, notes of chocolate and spices in the nose. Big bubbles all over the glass (of course, its brut). Decent maltiness, notes of caramel dried fruits and mild touch of chocolate. Touch of alcohol in rather dry finish. Slightly sweeter than Malheur Brut but also very complex and lovely brew.

Bottle at Chicago RB gathering.  Pour is deep mahogany with a medium tan head.  Aroma is caramel malt,light spice, and belgian yeast.  Flavor is Smooth caramel malt an light spice.  Pretty standard flavor, but the mouthfeel was like eating cotton candy.  The beer was there, and then bubbled into nothing.  Quite different.  it was good, but I felt like it interfered with some of the subtle flavors in the beer.

750 ml bottle sample courtesy of BBB. Pours a dark brownish hue, some lighter bits but very dark, a tannish head that sticks around moderate, laces ok. Dark, murky. Aromas are banana and delicate yeast, fruity with some darker sugar notes. Initial is smooth, a bit boozy, with banana esters, light spice, grains, with a decent yeastiness sticking to the palate. Light bitterness, fruity and lively, this beer is just a touch darker, some mellow sweetness instead of in your face. Nice.

2005 bottle shared by BBB63 at the chicagoland ratebeer gathering-  thanks MIke! Pours a deep brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of bread, dusty cocoa, some prune like fruits and doughy yeast.  Flavor has a hint of chocolate, more cocoa, fruits, and bread.   Alcohol is well hidden.  This is my first time tasting this beer, but I can imagine it has smoothed out quite a bit over the past 4+ years.  Maybe a little too much, as it lacks the big chocolately punch I was expecting.

The sample I tried was aged (and aged well) for four years in the cellar of BBB63. The most striking thing about this beer is the remarkably light texture. It was like drinking a cloud. It almost incredibly felt like it wasnt even wet as it crossed my tongue. At this age, a raisin sweetness dominates the flavor and aroma but, as I mentioned, it doesnt come across heavy in any way. I really found this to be an exceptional beer, esp. in terms of mouthfeel.

Deep brown beer with red glow and small beige foam on top. Aroma of caramel, spices, christmas cake and fruits. Taste is rich and smooth with loads of cereals, caramel, malts, fruits and spices, some alcohol warmth in the finale.

75cl bottle, poured in a plastic champagne glass at NYE. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is freash bread, yeast, brown sugar and sweet red wine. Flavor is very sweet and delicate. Slightly bittersweet finish. Medium carbonation. Nice brew.

Dark rich pour with a small head. Retains with some legs. Aroma is sweet, caramel, molasses, some roasted malts, toffee and cocoa. Flavor is sweet, bubbly, some rich bittersweet chocolate, dark roasted malts and rich dark fruit, figs and molasses.

Draft at Flying Saucer (thanks for footing the bill, Frank!) Very dark brown, sparkling brew that pours with a big head, then fades to a small cap. Smells like some kind of exotic fruit pie, maybe a baked mincemeat. Starts off with a mild plum/raisin flavor profile that builds in the mouth. Cranberry, a bit of meat, and a pleasant warming finish. The champagne-like finish is fitting for this high-brow, fancy brew.

Pours a very dark chestnut brown color with slight amber hues when held to a light source and a 2.5 frothy beige head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Minimal lacing.

Chocolate malt aroma with some peppery spice subtle roastiness, sweet alcohol and estery dark fruit notes. Hints of raisin, plum and fig.

Nicely carbonated with a sweet effervescent body/flavor. Estery belgian yeast provides a lot of dark fruit flavor, namely dark cherry, plum, grape and raisin. Slight roasty chcolate malt and minimal hop bitterness. ABV is very well masked. Dry finish.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brune body with a tan head.  Strong fruity body with apples, plums and etoh warming.  Dark chocolate, coco, nutty with hints of vanilla and coffee.  Bitter sweet with a serious alcohol warming.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours a reddish brown with a beige/brown head. Aromas of sour cherries, lemon, dark fruits, sultanas, candied peel, cinammon, coriander. Flavours of vanilla, marzipan, nutmeg, raisins, slight hops. Finishes sweet, malty and mildly hoppy. A veritable christmas pudding of a beer! Lovely stuff!
Rich cocoa aroma.  Lightly sweet malty flavor with notes of clove, licorice, and anise.  Nice champagne effervescence.  Quite elegant.

15cl sample from 75cl bottle at 3rd Brugs BF. Deep dark brown colour, off white head with big bubbles. Aroma is light buttery, floral, caramel. Flavour is malty, caramel, light flowery, some butterscotch, dry bitter light coffee finish. Just a bit over-carbonated imo. Medium bodied. Aroma was a bit off, I guess the glass wasnt cleaned properly.

Rating #1000. 750ml green bottle, corked. Best before 01/01/2009. Dark brown colour, burgundy highlights. Tan head settles into a nice creamy layer, some modest sticky ace on the glass. Aroma has a ntoe of orange, chocolate and background alcohol. Flavour is malty with chocolate undetones, fruity hints of red grape, orange, yeast, some fruitiness. Yeasty finish with a subtle bitterness and more background chocolate notes and spice. Champagne like carbonation, creamy body.

Bottle courtesy of ericandersnavy. Pours a dark cola brown to black with one finger tan head that settles slowly. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of ripe dark fruit, caramel, toffee, rum soaked raisins, light chocolate and fudge notes. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of caramel, toffee, ripe dark fruit, yeast, bready wheat, some light spice, candy sugar, light notes of molasses. Generally medium body with a slight fizzy, malty finish. Interesting beer.

Thanks to hobbersr for sharing this ridiculously expensive beer.  Has a fruity aroma, almost saison like.  A subtle and bitter-sweet taste of grapes, watermelon and citrus.  A very champagne like mouthfeel, not surprisingly.  Pours light brown with decent lacing.
Bottle thanks to swalden28.  Poured an auburn brown with cream head.  Aroma was of choclate, caramel, cranberry, and a hint of orange.  Flavor was of spice, choclate, bourbon, and grape.  GOOD BEER!

Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a dark brown with thick tan head. Aroma is light farmhouse, fruit, toasted grain, light caramel and malt. Flavor has some light toasted grain, little farmhouse, some sweetness, malty, candy sugar, spicey and pepper. Mouth feel is medium body with lively, fizzy carbonation. Overall, not a bad beer at all, but not worth the retail price.

Courtesy of unknown generous person at RSBG Grand Tasting. Pours dark brown with medium foam. Aroma is of brown sugar, a little alcohol, and dark fruit. Flavor is of dark berries, brown sugar, a little alcohol again. Full palate, chewy. Overall, excellent.

Bottle from Dranken Geers. Definitely felt a little let down. Pretty pricy and didnt justify the extra expense. Usually I know that spending the extra few pennies is worth it. Didnt feel that way this time. Brown with a healthy pale brown head. Hops and malt, a little sourness, some dark fruits and yeast, bitter finish. Certainly not a bad beer by any stretch, just wouldnt buy another at that price when there are much better options.

This draft brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a hazy with fine particulate typically carbonated dark brown colored body. The aroma was hoppy brown malt and dark malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a bubbly aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of vinous and brown malt. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Poured dark cola color with a tight head. Nose had hints of chocolate, prunes, and spicy yeast esthers. Taste had raisin, plum, prunes, dark chocolate, but is beaten to hell in back with the massive carbonation.

From the Bottle at Dr Bills Tasting Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 09/10/2008
Hoppy aroma. Amber red coloured and strong in alcohol with a crisp and very bitter bourbon finish.

bottle thanks to swalden28 for my birthday. best before june 30, 2008. poured a dark brown/reddish with a great khaki head. aroma of orange, plum, cinnamon, pastries, yeast, grape, other fruits and spices. flavor was orange, cinnamon, vinous notes, alcohol, and earthy spices. body was medium-full with high carbonation. flavor improved greatly once it warmed a bit. thanks again to my brother for this birthday present.

750ml bottle.  Pours extremely dark with deep orange when held to light. Huge gray head thats very active and continues to foam up after pouring. The aroma is mostly alcoholic, yeasty and quite spicy. To taste this is quite sweet but also a touch thin? alcohol burn, musty character and a touch metallic. Overall this is easy drinking, powerful and strong, interesting but not outstanding.

Aged, woody nose, oxidated flavor with deep grape and vinous notes.  Fizzy, champagne like palate.  Excellent example of something, but Im not sure what.  Cellaring maybe. Bottle shared at RBSG 2009 grand tasting.

0,75 l Champagne bottle. Luxury appearance with rich ruby red, dark, tawny orange color and tiny half-finger creamy head with excellent lacing.
Tricky, almost undescribable aromas and flavors. Tasted in DeuS flute glass. Spicy aroma at first with moderate champagne (or sherry?) like tartness.
Not as dark fruity or heavy roasted as expected. Much more complex and tricky with unique toasted maltiness, some resinous hops, cinammon and champagne dryness at the finish.
Dangerously well hidden alcohol, medium to full bodied. Slight acid dark grape notes matched with interesting, slightly wild (i mean barnyardy) champagne yeast aromas. Undescribable floral dryness.
I tried with belgian lavender spiced dark chocolate, but i think this brew is enough complex to drink itself. Unique experience, i also feel like a little bit underrated here.

I did not enjoy this beer. It was too weird tasting for my liking. Too much alcohol.
bman1113vr apprently didnt mind that aspect, but it was too much for a light weight like me.

Big thanks to m4est88 for this aged bottle. Best before date of 01/01/2009. Pours with a large khaki head over a deep, murky brown body. Good belgian lace. Aroma of brandy, dark fruits, grand manier, light oxidation, chocolate, cherry and orange peel. Taste is chocolate, raisins, creamy nearly toasted toffee, jam, figs, sherry and vanilla. Long duration. Alcohol is kept in check easily. Creamy mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Excellent, but not something to get anytime soon at $25.

0,75 l bottle. Deep ruby body with a discreet but delicious creamy tan head. Fantastic complex aroma with a lot of spicies like vanilla, coriander and clove, the finest belgian top-fermentation yeasts, some toasted malt, light fruity character. Smooth mouthfeel, fine balanced body with toasty caramel malt, fine fruity tastes, vanilla and honey character, well balanced easy hops. Well hidden high percentage of alcohol. You can not feel it.... Complex palate and aftertaste.. The beer is underrated here, one of the best beers what ive ever tried!

Bottle from Root Cellar. 

Poured clear dark brown color with an average  frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate toasted malt, yeast and alcohol aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium complex bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration.

My expectations where met with an above average for style brew.

Extreme dark brown body with hints of red, a two inch tan cap reduced down to about half an inch but this lasted the rest of the beer and left behind lots of lacing. Aroma was made up of sweet alcohol but not as much as youd think given the massive content in here, spice, yeast, wheat, and grape juice. Mouth feel was all right but just maybe a touch thin. Taste is pretty good starts off sweet and turns into a clean bitterness in the finish, taste milder than I expected from this big beer. Wood, grape juice that also sometimes taste like watermelon jolly ranchers, dark light tasting malts and some spice all make up the flavor. Taste is so much milder then I would have ever guessed and the alcohol is hidden very well, I would recommend this to any one because its a very easy drinking beer but easy drinking is not something you normally look for in the style. Like I said its good but not stand outish.

Picked this one up in a bargain bin. Nice find! Great, fresh aroma, rare belgian without banana aroma, but a great flavor of mixed fruits and clean linen. Sweet barley throughout with little aftertaste except a hint of dryness.

Sizable light beige head that recedes quickly but leaves decent lace on the glass. Deep brown, but bright light can still shine through. 

Sweet aroma of brandy with a touch bitterness from the darker malts. Somewhat earthy. 

Very sweet flavor with a touch of hop at the swallow. Described as the "Perfect Match to Belgian Chocolate", which may be true. But this is a brew that should be sipped. It is very rich, but with a good level of carbonation. Strong Sherry-like flavors. This doesnt taste like a typical Belgian; there isnt the Belgian yeast flavoring Id expect. Despite the alcohol level, this is a deceptive beer. Certainly it would be hard to drink this regularly.

Sample at 3rd Annual Great Austin Belgian Beer Festival on May 16, 2009.  Losing memory for the review (too many samples by this time), but I did manage to write down the numbers. Great color, a mahogany-red, with a sour, piney aroma.  Taste of pine and pit fruits, a very dark constitution.

Bottle. 
Pours ruby with a small tan head. 
Aroma is prunes, malt and yeast with a weak note of raisins. 
Flavour is raisins, prunes, and caramel. 
The alcohol is very well hidden. Nicely balanced.

Botella. Clear reddish golden colour with a medium off-white head. Aroma of yeast, mild fruit and caramel. Sweet caramel, yeasty, lightly bitter fruity flavour with a chocolate touch. Soft pleasant champagne brew.

75 bottle shared by faroeviking.
clear dark brown, small light brown head.
aroma if chocolate and yeast. mild / faint aroma.
flavor is sweet chocolate, dark fruits, caramel, very faint cork. overall appears a little fruity. some alc.

Nice ruby brown color with a tall, dried bone colored head. Much lighter (in the sense that it smells like a lighter colored brew) aroma than expected, at least at first. THe initial burst is of pale malts and light floral hops. After it settles for a bit, the aromas darken with plums, honey, light anise and light yeast. Lightly toasted malt start. Quite light and airy on the palate. Fruit joins in the middle with just a touch of sweetness. I want to say a mild bitterness, but it really is more than I think to keep all the sweetness in check. A very nice balance in this one. Malt, anise, fruit, toasted almonds, and a hint of light chocolate. Unless you suck the foam, as a result of an over-pour, the alcohol is not to be found. I find this to be a very refined imperial dubbel. A dangerous brew.
Reddish brown pour.  Spicey, chocolate, dark fruit, malty, caramel.  Overall not too interesting.

(Sample Date: 1/1/2009   Source:Mekong)   Sampled at Ans New-Years Party. Very malty with spicy Belgian character. Mostly clear medium amber brown with small head, sparkling. Tastes a lot like a dunkel but with a Belgian yeast. Finish is dry and spicy.
bottle @Zythos, brown, small head, medium thick, fruity, dry. It was not the super beer I was expecting, but still a quit good beer!

Poured a hazy, reddish amber color with a filmy white head. Sweet and malty aroma with some nice chocolatey notes. Really rich flavor. Very malty and sweet with a strong caramel flavor. Very smooth and has a champagne-like mouthfeel. Easy to drink - which is dangerous for this high alcohol beer.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2009 Tasted @ Zythos march 7th 2009. All our Malheur disappeared like snow for the sun when we got a hold of this fine black brewsky. Elaborated picks of dark mouts and a well balanced palate of hop bitters, together with a champagne yeast to give it its feasty finish. I was not yet worthy for thy. Some occasion will arise soon I hope. A Cum Laude beer!

Bottle @ Zythos 2009. A clear brown colored beer, with a smal beige head. The aroma is fruity like citrus with raisins. There is a little caramel. And madeira like. The taste is a little sparkling like and it has notes of champagne, with caramel malt. Fruits like raisins with notes of sherry. The aftertaste is a little bitter with some sweet.
Aroma is sweet and malty with some dried fruit coming through. Texture is creamy and buttery. Sweet flavour with some banana, caramel and bourbon-like maltiness.

Pours a murky cola colour with a medium sized head with fine bubbles. Aroma is sweeter than expected. Apples and plums on the nose with hints of chocolate, belgian yeast, and a little red berries. Tastes like apples and plums initially with some sour cherry, hints as raspberry, chocolate, white glue (in a pleasant way), and vanilla. Mouthfeel is extremly pleasant, its a very heavy beer brightened up by the fine champagne like carbonation. Great beer!

Labeled as Black Chocolate.  750 ml bottle shared at Woodshop.  Dark dark pour with tan head that was a pretty good size.  Sweet malty flavors and aromas.  Dark fruits and molasses.  Some wood and some chocolate.  Pretty good.

This was my "happy 27th birthday" beer.  Pours a dark brown raisin color with a tan head that starts large and fades to a brown film.  Nice haze.  Aroma is of wood, grass, Very subtle mustard spice, hay, a little caramel, raisin, and oaked chardonnay.  Flavor of sweet caramel, raisin, cocoa, chardonnay, tart spice, grass.  Finishes pretty sweet, but with subtle mustard and cinnemon notes.  Sugar coated pecans on the aftertaste.  Full bodied, high carbonation that is prickly at first but feels fluffier over time.  I like how the sweetness is contrasted with the ever so slightly sour (like sourdough bread) elements.  A slight cloying feel is the only flaw.  Nice!  Oh yeah, its NOT called Black Chocolate in the US anymore, just Dark Brut.

[Sampled in gråsten.] Vintage 2003, 5 years old. Almost no yeast left, but lots of old notes of sweetness, dried fruits, plums, oaky, whisky, vinous, dry and very complex with many old notes. Great beer to forget in the cellar.
Woodshop Quad. Nose was light hoppy bitterness, caramel, and some cocoa. Lightly hazy gold with a big off white head. Flavor was lightly funky, caramel, and a touch of cherries

Bottle:  Poured a brown color with a thick head.  The aroma was sweet chocolate, caramel and some fruit.  The flavor was a touch tart, mostly sweet chocolate and dark fruits.  Overall, quite a tasty brew.

Bottle: Poured a deep brown color ale with a nice thick foamy head with great retention and some lacing. Aroma consists of sweet barley malt is very enticing. Taste is a nice balance between some sweet barley malt with notes of caramel. Full body with great carbonation and no alcohol was apparent.  Very well done but unfortunately this is lacking character and I couldn’t justify paying that kind of rpice for that experience more then once.

Cloudy brown with mad off-white bubbles. Gushed despite very careful opening. However, a quickly disappearing head. Aroma of milk chocolate, bubblegum, caramel, and pineapple with touches of herbs and pepper making it a little interesting. Sweet cocolate flavour with licorice and pepper. Caramel sweetness makes it a little cloying. I thought I noticed a little brettanomyces in the finish. Slightly funky, and may also go with the pineapple aroma.
Flaske: Flot mørkebrun øl med et livligt skum. Lækker afbalanceret smag af nødder og chokolade, hvor alkoholen er en del af øllen i modsætning til sin lyse bror. Virkelig en treat.

Pours deep noir into a trappist glass.  Biege head with excellent retention leaves sheets and recedes to coat surface. Pit fruit aromas. Creamy with dark caramel, maple and pit fruit. Lasting, dusty finish.
Pours dark amber brown, CO2, dark fruits, malty, little tart, little yeasty, little spice.

From the bottle at Brugge 2008.  Hazy.  Rather a good dark fruity beer.  Slighly yeasty, but it also has roasted choc.  Lovely, good sherberty hop.  Great intense malt and hop aroma.  Wonderful in mouth, great finish.

Pours dark caramel with a light tan, fizzy head. It gushes as I pop the cork. The nose is a tart cherry funk with some sweet malt lingering. The flavor goes a bit more malt like a Christmas Belgian ale with some sour funk in the mid, followed by a sweet finish and smooth mouthfeel. Very nice.
750 ml bottle.  Somewhat more rich and more complex than its Brut brother, and certainly more interesting than its Deus brother and a fraction of the cost.  Try it after a few yers of storage.

75 cl bottle at my 40 y party, thanks to yngwie. Hazy dark brown color, beige/light brown head. Aroma is sweet dried fruit and malt. Flavor is malty and sweet with dried fruit, and some spice and yeast.

Muddy dark brown pour with a champagne like head. Lots of over ripe fruity sweetness in the aroma with yeasty spice, and wine like alcoholic notes. Lots of fruity dark malts in the flavor too. Very fruity, somewhat spicy and yeasty. Lots of carbonation, and a very dry finish. Interesting, but not for me.

750ml bottle.  Been storing this bad boy in the closet until I realized it was five months past its best by date.  Mild dark Belgian aroma.  Pours a thick brown with a hint of amber.  Opaque in a glowing way.  Big foamy dissipating head that I would assume would have been more formidable had this been cracked open a year back.  Holds up nonetheless certainly.  Relatively light and champagne like mouthfeel, with a similar sweet alcohol presence.  Very interesting twist.  Dark smooth Dubbel tastes.  This is fantastic stuff.  Mildly sour, this is exceptionally balanced stuff.  I hope I have the pleasure of trying this beer again.
Very dark amber color, thin even off-white head.  Spicy malty aroma, slightly pepper and raisin.  Pretty even sweet taste, moderate Belgian yeast, sweet finish.

Thanks to whomever brought this to Backus’s house for the Bash.  Dark brown color.  Taste was mostly brown sugar and dark fruits with some sour apples thrown in there.  I think this wierd sourness kind of turned me off.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2009 7/28/2007:  Malheuer Dark Brut pours a clear, sparkling mahogany brown color with a foamy beige head.  the aroma has some yeastiness and brown sugar.  Dark caramel malt, plums, and something spicy (cinnamon)? comprise the mildly sweet flavor.  There is some bitterness in the finish that adds balance to the malty sweetness.  This beer has a meidum body and isnt overly fizzy.  This is the second champagne-style beer that I have had.  It is good overall with some interesting complexities.
Sample from 750 corked and caged bottle (Alc 12% by Vol. / Best before end 30/06/?) shared at the "Columbus Tasting: Ate, now with gramatical errors" event.  Thanks!  Rating #270 for this beer.  Rating: 6/4/7/3/14=3.4. . . . . . . . . .5/26/2009:  Malheur Dark Brut (Dark Reserve) has a really nice mahogany brown color with a thin, barely perbeptable beige head.  It has the bubbly carbonation like chapagne accompanied by a refined, difficult to describe aroma.  By best stab at describing the aroma is fruity, spicy, light, cola, cherry, and a tinge of alcohol.  This beer is light and airy on the palate without feeling over carbonated.  It is fruity and dark with hints of dark berries and chocolate followed by a dry, Belgian-like finish.  The alcohol isnt immediately discernable, but it is definitely there and goes to the head after a few good gulps.  After awhile, an interesting mildly tongue-numbing herbal quality starts to take over.  Overall, this is a pretty good beer, but not really my style and definitely not woth the cost for me.

1 Pint 9.45 fl. oz. corked and caged bottle (Alc 12% by Vol.; Best before end 088/110) shared by .  Thanks!  Rating:  7/4/8/3/15=3.7

750mL bottle, courtesy of bitbucket.  Thanks again, Bob!  Pours a dark, ruby-wooden color; off-white head with patchy lacing.  Lots of dried dark fruits, peppery yeastiness, and dates / raisins / malty sweetness in the nose; dried fruits throughout.  Lively carbonation.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lots of dried dark fruits (dates, raisins), yeastiness, pepper, and lively fizziness; touches of alcoholic warmth; intense, lively Champagne-like, yeasty beer.  Lengthy finish: doughiness, white pepper, and dry, dense yeast.

Sampled @ Backus’s Backdoor Bash.Poured a dark amber with a nice foamy head.This was the biggest suprise of the day for me.A nice chocolaty nose.Flavor was dark fruits, chocolate with some swettness and crispiness.Finished off sweet.
Bottle courtesy of the funess that was Backuss Backdoor Bash 08. Pour was clear dark brown. Aroma of brown sugar. Flavor was caramel and figs. Very sweet. Very nice!

Tasting at mcbackus 10/19.  Hell  yes this is a great beer.  Dark brown pour, fluffy tan head.  Aroma of malt, wood, caramel, sugar...mmmmm!  Flavor is woody, malty, a bit sweet.  Great mouthfeel.  Simply a delicious beer.

75 cl bottle, thanks ekstedt. Brown, cloudy, with a mostly diminishing, creamy, off-white head leaving virtually no lacing. Notes of caramel and raisin. Light to moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Light to medium bodied, creamy, with fizzy carbonation.

Bottle, 75 cl. Tasted yesterday with William and WBF team.
(bougth @ Hopduvel)
Almost black color, with thick, creamy, beige head. 
Aroma sweet, malts, dark fruits, spice.
Medium to full body.
Taste starts sweet, spice, some fruits, and complex.
Good stuff.

Bottle opens with a huge, resounding POP!  Westy 12 like in appearance, thin, creamy, cobwebby head, and a darkbrown with reddish edges.  I’m immediately comparing this to some great Belgian quadruppels, specifically Rochefort 10, Westy 12, maybe St. Bernardus 12.  It has the kind of blueberry-like element of the Rochefort, the beautiful malt and dark fruits of all three.  The feel is a touch thin.  Not boozy, very lively, spritzy, deep, and elegant.  Extremely underrated given the huge appeal this should have for anyone who likes the big belgian quads.

Man, I’m trashed...
Poured out a small sized rocky, light tan head that has good retention and some spotty lacing over a nice dark, hazy brown brew. The aroma is very nice and mild with obvious sweetness, fruit (candy raspberries, blackberries), a bit of caramel, weak wood, chocolate, slight herb and probably vanilla. The taste is amazing and instantly comes across as highly drinkable: immediate fruit (raspberries, strawberry, raisin), caramel. The spice in surprisingly soft - the total lack of alcohol here is impressive to say the least. Round the flavour out with plums, fig, earth, licorice,... mmm. Not as good as the aroma but there is no stopping drinking this entire bottle. Mouth feel disappoints as it does come across light  an don times empty feeling but, hey, sometimes that is better than a face full of yeast. Finishes very smooth with a bit of a drying while keeping a bit of film. This truly is a killer brew - it’s a pisser that it costs 23$ a bottle here!

Bottle (EBF2008)
Sweet fruity hoppy aroma. Lovely dark berry and sherbet - raspberry?   A little flat palate, almost water - hard to believe this is 12% - but there’s a big hoppy tingle. On swallowing, it’s soft and malty - absolutely lovely.

Bottle at EBF 2008.
Hazy brown with a off white head. Aroma heavy malty (dark fruits, chocolate). Flavor moderate/heavy sweet. Full body, sparkling.

Bottle @ EBF Nice brown and murky color. Aroma is a bit chocolate but mostly sweet and with some dark fruits. Taste is a bit spicey with lots of dark fruits and a bit chocolat. A bit to much carbonation.

Poured a very dark brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma of cinnamon and dark fruits, a bit of caramel and toffee.  Flavor is surprisingly spicy with notes of licorice dominating over dark fruits, leading to a somewhat spicy toffee-ish finish.  Complex and good, and though not what I was expecting from a strong Belgian, has some merits in its own right.  I’d still prefer something a tad more traditional, though.

Clear garnet with a rocky head. Aroma is yeasty pepper spice with dark raisons and dates. Medium body with a busy mouthfeel. Good flavors are earthy, yeasty, with dark caramel brown sugar and sweet raisons. A really tasty strong ale here.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 750 ML Shared Bottle-Pours a cloudy dark brown color w/some traces of mahogany & a moderate creamy tan head. Sweet, carbonated aroma. Flavors of dark fruit-plums/cherries/raisens, w/some figs, bread dough, almonds, colander, & candied sugar. Had a lot of carbonation & a lot of levels; pretty complex stuff. Id almost have to try it again to get a better read on it. Long, sweet, carbonated finish; definite after dinner sipper. Alcohol was well hidden.

750, corked, baled, and foiled, at Brouwer’s. Thanks, Deanna! Pours a grainy, opaque, and nearly black ebony...still shows some dark brown highlights, barely, here and there. Thick, creamy, pillowy tan head that lasts and lasts. Mild brown sugar, brown bread, and light fig and spice overtones. Creamy body on the high side of medium, a bit of soft and gentle carb. The breads, sugars, fruits, and spices blend into a perfect complex mid-palate. It’s difficult to do justice to all the different elements swirling around the tongue with this beer. Moderately long and intense nutty, bready finish. Wonderful stuff.

750ml bottle shared at Houston BA tasting.  Pours a dark brown with an off-white head.  Nose is of yeast and spice.  Taste is of yeast and spice, but also dark fruits - raisins for one.  Mouthfeel is medium with super carbonation

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of dark ripe fruits, chocolate, raisins, and caramel.  Poured dark brown in color with a medium-sized, dense, beige head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Fully of tiny particles.  Sparkling.  Medium sweet flavor.  Tastes of malts, plums, dark ripe fruits, chocolate, and yeast.  Medium body.  Tingly, chalky texture.  Lively carbonation.  Sweet, lightly dry finish.  12%ABV is well hidden.

Pours an effervescent dark ruby, with a foamy, lasting lace - the aroma is quite yeasty up front, but there is a lot of complexity hiding underneath, with a lot of peppery notes, dark fruit skins, a dusty, cobweb-ish character, subtle herbs - the alcohol is fairly apparent underneath, though, adding a tinge of acetone that takes away from the other pleasant characteristics - full, tingly carbonation in the mouth - much like the aroma, the flavor starts off rather yeasty, but this fades quickly - behind that comes some soft wildflower flavors, particularly lavender - after this, a very mild sweetness comes to the fore, with a gentle fruit quality (date/raisin) - becomes dry again quickly, and quite spicy/peppery as well - this works well with the continuing floral notes - dry, peppery finish - the alcohol barely shows its head at all - not mindblowing, but this is rather understated and subtle for something of such strength.
75cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex, but heavy, hazy, good head, very good brew, more balanced than the Malheur 12, very expensive

first burn sp*** ... pours with a island destroying tsunami tidal wave effervescent head, stained my carpet with the huge run-off ... lots of head and nice lacing ... what a beer for such a shitty night, this beer turned the tide ... no abv even thought about ... delicious stuff!! ...fuck it, i quit!

Definatly the true champagne of beers unlike that high life swill. Pours dark with aromas of chocolate and dark malt with a carbonated lacing. Holds the glass tremendously well and is enjoyable, might start popping these babies on new years.

A: Fruity & yeasty, malt, caramel, toffee and plenty of alcohol as the glass warms.  A: Massive foam when first opened and chilled.  Deep brown/red.  F: Similar to the aroma with plenty of fruity yeasty esters, faint cocoa, toffee and caramel malt. As the glass warms, the toffee, caramel become more dominant with some strong alcohol.  P: ample carb with a dry finish.  O: Nice BSA with plenty of character to keep you interested through out the glass.  Have had plenty others as good or better so I would take that into consideration for a subsequent purchase.

750ml from The Good Beer Store, Chapel Hill (RIP). Got this one at the mega-discount closing sale, or else I might feel a wee bit ripped off. The "black chocolate" I would certainly count as a misnomer since, immediately in the nose, this beer reveals itself to be a very fruity Belgian strong with little in the way of the darker flavors. This bottle is from ca. 2003-2004, so I might have a different impression with a young bottle. But it’s super-heavily carbonated with a very active mouthfeel. Impressive hops remain, bringing out some cola and berry flavors (no heavy dark fruits for the most part). Not much change as the beer warms up. Alcohol is subdued for the most part, and the finish is syrupy sweet. Okay, but not hugely impressive.
Poured a reddish brown color with no head. Aroma was mainly of dark fruits and malts. Flavor was much the same of dark fruits, some candy sugar, pretty dry though.

750ml bottle. Cloudy dark orange with a huge head. Lots of lace. Aroma of  toffee, hard fruity candy and yeast^2. Very sweet, candy-like taste with a tangy texture. I’ll probably buy another the next time I see it for $12.

750 ml, cork and cage (best by 1/1/09).  Dark, almost opaque, chestnut pour with red around the edges - fluffy tan head.  Well balanced aroma of yeast and caramel malt up front.  Subdued dark fruit, blueberry, and some cocoa waaay in the distance.  Dates.  Similar flavor, classic BSA candi sugar and slightly sticky body.  Toffee and caramel for sure.  Great finish - toffee, caramel, bitter greens.  Peppery, dry, astringent finish.  Leaves something to be desired but still great.  Way too expensive.

Bottle. Sweet nose, caramel and figs with some alcohol presence and a touch of raspberry. Cloudy brown pour with a thin head. Mild sweetness, very well balanced with caramel notes and some light peach. Clean palate and good body.

Bottle: pours a dark brownish color with a thin tan head, malty and yeasty aroma, taste of caramel and dark bitter chocolate with some carbonation and leaves a fairly dry finish in the mouth.  I was fortunate enough to get this bottle for 1/2 price at an event at Capones.  Glad to have had the chance to try it.

Sampled at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, Minnesota. Shared by BDR and Badgerben. Pours a semi-clear dark copper brew with a creamy off-white head that slowly dissipates to a creamy top and some good lacing. Aroma of dark raisin, prunes, dark pitted fruits, some orange zest and a touch of brown sugar. Taste is full bodied, light carbonation, flavors of dark malt, light yeast,  raisins, dark pitted fruit and some lemon zest. Finish is semi-sweet, with an aftertaste of brown sugar and dark malt. An interesting dark strong ale.

Pours dark cloudy brown, with a big off-white head.  Nose is of yeast, malt, roasted malt, caramel.  Taste is malty and fruity.  Yeast is very present, making the beer pretty dry.  Body is relatively light, with all of the carbonation.  Light alcohol in the finish.  A little like drinking a champaigne.  Not bad.

Bottle shared with and courtesy of heavy (huge thanks!) 2003 vintage if Im not mistaken. Damn Im glad I didnt have to pay for this. It foamed out of the bottle and turned out to be of a dark dark brown-red colour with an off white medium sized head.  The nose is as complex as expected. Dark malt, some raisins and sugar, orange, chocolate, wine.  The taste wasnt far off. Smooth mouthfeel, deep dark maltiness (tannines I reckon as well), a bit oakey, some chocolate. some dust. Spicey orange taste. Ever so slightly vinuous. Rosewater? All in all, a very respectable beer that I was very happy to try.

26/05 0.75 l bottle purchased at belgianshop.com. Opened with very strong pop, a bit spilled out of the bottle, when poured into glass it had dark reddish brown body with big brownish head which lived pretty short. Nice aroma, sweetish caramel with spices, some wood like oak and also sourish component like lemon or grapefruit. Flavor is very nice, but I still miss that expunged yeast. Its very well balanced between bitter and sweet, I expected to be more brut, more bitter. Offers whole range of flavors such as chocolate, caramel, plums, orange, other fruits, sugar, cola, spices etc. I also must say alcohol is not felt at all, I mean, at 12% its hidden so well I couldnt believe. Finish is long, pretty smooth and caramel sweet. Dangerously drinkable, pairs great with chocolate indeed. Expensive, yes, maybe too much, but its great beer.

750ml bottle. Poured a clear medium brown color with orange light shining through. Head was light tan. Smelled of anise, cola, and subdued brown sugar. Very effervescent (turbo carbonation as heemer said) which lightened up the body some. Slightly sweet and spicy with a splash of alcohol warmth. I tasted dilute brown sugar, cola, and raw alcohol.

On beer 4.  Very highly carbonated - surprisingly slides down the throat easily.  The aroma is very sweet - almost grape.  Very easy drinking beer.  A slight almost woody/oaky taste emerges on the swallow and ends with a sweet aftertaste!

Ridiculously easy to drink!  One more bar keep!  Oh, wait...  at $34, lets wait until I get paid again!

Slightly malty slightly funky aroma almost fantome-like nose.  Pours dark brown with a thick tan head.  Big spicy flavors, malty and sweet with caramel and hints of cinnamon and anise, slight roastiness.  very interesting, very diverse flavors.  Awesome!!

0.75 l bottle. Hazy very dark reddish color with bubbly head. Fruity, tart, peppery and vinous aroma with black currant, dark fruits, leather and ginger. Tart fruity flavor with notes of prunes, figs, pepper, alcohol, licorice, chocolate, port wine and some wild yeast character. Slightly astringent finish. Fairly warming and a hot on alcohol. Highly Complex and unique beer. Best of the champagne beers.

Pours hazy deep brown with some ruby edges and 3-fingers or so of khaki head.  Nose is malty, figgy, with notes of brown sugar, rock sugar, some tart fruits including cherry and blackberry, and mild port notes.  The taste is malty, brown sugary, with a definite champagne yeast flavor and effervescence, some figgy and dark fruit, and a definite twang of cherry tartness and freshly picked blackberries.  Wonderfully complex and lively on the palate, this one is very good.

The beer pours a clear brown amber with a thick light brown head. The nose is a great mix a burnt sugar and dark fruit, mainly raisins and plums. The taste is great I get raisins plums, dark stone fruit, and wood. The beer is very lively on the tongue with a dry hoppy finish. I would call this a great beer and worth the money.

[bottle] Poured at a blind tasting at the Cellars. Pours clear brown with a large tannish head. Nose is predominantly caramel with some yeast and some sweetness from the alcohol. Flavor is pretty sweet, with brown sugar, caramel, and alcohol. Finish is somewhat dry with some good hop bitterness.

Sticky, sweet, and balanced. Served in my Orval glass. Huge foamy head, beer came gushing out at uncorking -- have your glass ready! Notes of chocolatecocoa, hazelnut, honey, dark fruit (raisin, plum), and spices. Well balanced. The carbonation wasnt as spritzy as the champagne beers Lust or DeuS, which made Malheur Brut Noir a bit more drinkable than the others. The 12.5% abv is very well hidden. Priced at $27.99.
(Bottle at Pikkulintu on 2008-02-20) Dark amber colour. Good head. Sweetness, yeast and some hops in nose. Sweetness, fruitiness from yeast and chocolate in taste. Dry palate.

Picked up for a ridiculously cheap sale price of $10 at Greens, this 750 ml. Champagne style bottle was impressive even before opening.  The loud pop while pulling out the cork was quite a bit like opening a Champagne, but the Burgundy colored liquid with a large foamy head looked nothing like it.  It was an impressive looking beer nonetheless.  Id almost call is a cross between St. Bernardus Abt. 12 and Duvel.  The smell was quite a fruit barrage, led mainly by red apples, and followed by cherry and strawberry.  The taste was quite a bit like a Quadrupel but without a lot of the intense alcohol.  The fruits detected by the nose were here with some raisins thrown in.  Earthy and spicy hop presence was detectable.  Amazingly easy to drink for such a big beer with a creamy and dry texture that just glided down with each sip.  Felt quite a bit lighter in the mouth than it really was, which i think was quite an intentional effect.  Much better than the Brut Reserve in my opinion, as this one tries not to imitate something else, and is a better drink as a result.

5-2-08 bottle shared at tasting 
Amber brown pour with a very bubbly head.  Smell is malt and some chocolate as well.  Taste and palate remind me of pepsi.  Weird.

Pours a rich maroon opaque color with a nice sized fizzy head atop.  Smell is dark caramel, and raisons.  Taste is the same with burnt, tart and sweet raisons and dark caramel with an incredibly fizzy, bubbly and foamy mouthfeel that I tend to not like.  Champaign like mouthfeel, in fact.  Certainly isnt bad, but the mouthfeel really inhibits the enjoyability for me.

Pours a lovely dark brown-black with a great tan head & lacing. Massive chocolate aroma! Tastes very nice - lightly tart at first, and opens up into a warm ifnish. Lots of chocolate. Creamby body with great carb - wow! I like how unique this beer is.

Bottle, bought @ LIVA, Domhusgade, Kolding.
Pours deep red, nutty-brown with a giant, frothy off-white head. Aroma is sweet with plenty of fruits, grapes, plums, light buttery and some chocolate. Extremely deep and creamy mouthfeel. Magnificent flavour, lots of chocolate, plenty of viniousness, deep, dark fruits; wonderful complexity. Light dryness, a touch of tartness, lowish carbonation, biscuit, plums and a bit of trees. Magnificent!

750 ml bottle from Monument in Concord, CA; corked & caged. Slightly vinous aroma with dark malt. Deep mahogany color with a fine beige head that guickly departed. Full bodied with creamy/fizzy carbonation. Starts with noticeable heat, dark roasted malt, and some chocolate. Seems to be a dark fruit component in the background. Its probably complex, but much of the complexity is hidden behind the malt for me. Finish is reasonably dry. Very tasty.
super fine head....lots of roasted malt in the nose..but super refined and balanced...great stuff.......the real champagne of beers! and my favorite of all the malheur beers!

Split with maniac, thanks to him for helping me haul that min-fridge up the stairs.  Pours a very dark brown with lots of tiny floaties.  Good initial head fades almost entirely.  Aroma of light cocoa.  Acrid carbonic bite, then the flavor is mostly light, powdery cocoa.  Candy sugar, faint plum.  OK, but not mind blowing.

Dark brown body with ruby highlights and a suspension of particulate stuff. Medium creamy tan head. Sweet rum soaked fruit, candi sugar, chocolate malts and a touch of tart. Flavor has lots of candi sugar, dark malts, rum soaked fruit. Medium-full body with moderately high carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2009 Rerate 2009: Dark brown with a huge head. Sweet aroma of raisins and brown sugar. The flavour is traditional Belgian strong ale with only a hint of brut. 

Old rating: Dark brown with a fine head. Sweet aroma of dried dark fruits, caramel and citric orange. Mind blowing flavours of toffee, a bit of chocolate and caramel. This is really something!

Nearly black, tan head, good lacing and retention. Aroma is soft with notes of dark sugars, darker fruits, some darker malts like chocolate as well. Somewhat unique flavors, maybe some spicing like anise here? Medium bodied, prickly yet delicate carbonation. 12% hidden amazingly. Much more enjoyable than the regular Brut, but its still too expensive to come back to.

750 ml corked bottle cellared for three years. Dense tanned  head. Body is lively and unclear chocolate-brown. An inviting sweetness to the nose, dark fruits, tropical,  pears and green apples detected. Pleasant whiffs of refined malts, chocolate, bubblegum, yeast and spices. Taste is complex and harmonious, Delicate sweetish malts, fruits, caramel, chocolate, pepper and herbs. Alcohol is very well masked. Carbonatied, but still a soft and gentle mouthfeel. Warm, dry and spicy finish. Outstanding!

Corked and caged bottle with a best before end date of 30/06/2008. Pours a large fizzy tan head that was mostly lasting, carbonation was fizzy, lively and fast rising, and the hue was reddish brown. Nose was malty, fruity, alcohol, some chocolate notes, and some pepper. Flavor was sweet, fruity, malty, vinuous, some chocolate, light pepper and finishes dry. Mouthfeel was slightly tingly along with a warming sensation. Medium body. Very quaffable, one of my favorite styles, very tasty even with the high ABV and one Ill drink again if it comes my way. Worthy of a try IMO.

Bottle, aged three years.
Liquorice, fennel, black pepper.
Spicy, light, harmonious. Prunes, raisins.
Vinous. Lovely.
Aroma of burnt fruit, some bubble gum and candy. Pours a dark ruby brown, with a off-tan head. Sweet, with prune/burnt fruit. Smooth, with slight warming alcohol finish.

Big bottle. BB4 01/01/2009. Dark brown with a moderate dark cream head. Light grass and pepper aroma. Seems subdued or restrained.  Flavour starts out chocolate, banana, pepper and alcohol. Then the alcohol builds to a kick-ass finish. As it warms the banana mellows the chocolate maintains its strength and the alcohol takes over your mind. A delicious mix.

Thanks Jason for sharing this Dark Brut labeled bottle.  750 mL.  Best by 1/15/2008.  I dont think its anywhere close to being past its prime.  The beer pours to a cola colored body with ruby highlights.  A tall dark tan head thats quite foamy with nice lacing sits on top.  The aroma is strongly yeasts (Belgian) with dark malts, and something like a robust cherry wood.  Theres very complex things going on here.  The flavors are sweet bread malts, earthy dark saison-like things and a nice woodsy thing like cherry wood.  The beer has a nice carbonation and sweet drying woody palate.  The alcohol is well hidden.

750ml bottle, a champagne dark brut belgian stron ale. Fizzed out of control upon opening, let setteled for a few. Incredible foamy light brown head. Aroma of sugars, fruits, raisins, nuts, malts and chocolate. Toasty flavor, some cocolate taste to this brut. Incredible to find out the alcohol is blended in nicely (12%). This was a beutiful beer, enjoyed my 250th on valantines day with my sweetheart.

Bouteille verte, avec bouchon de liège, de 750 ml partagée avec MartinT et Glouglouburp. Arôme: Odeur de malt caramélisé avec une pointe de chocolat et de citron. Apparence: La couleur est brune-bourgogne avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel fruité avec une pointe dépices. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de fumé en arrière goût. (Rating #1448)

Drinking from a 750ml bottle which, despite the notes on the beers page, is not called Black Chocolate in the Chicago region of the U.S. -  - The Champagne-like qualities of this dark beer immediately gassed m y system up with its hyper-effervesence.  Nice pour, a dark brown body topped off with a large fizzy beige head.  The first scent to reach my schnozz was a purple grape fruitiness followed by plums, dried out plums (prunes, if you must), toasted raisin bread with elderberry jam, dark malts, and a smattering of warm chocolate.  As hinted at afore, the body is light and highly, nigh superfluously carbonated.  The flavors a virtual flamora of a let-down, the main taste being sweet toasty dark malt.  Its soon joined by prunes (dried out plums, if you must), some burnt malt,,, but not a lot more.  I.e., the flavor doesnt match the expectations excited by the nose.  [And, at my age, you WANT those expectations to be met!]  Dont get me wrong.  This is a darned fine brew, but not what the exhorbitant cost for a bottle would lead you to believe it might be. On the plsu side, the alcoholohol really dosnt show its prsence til really neer theernd of the bottl.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Plainfield, IL<font size=-1>
Dark brown, fizzy light brown head with medium retention, no lace. Yeasty pruney aroma. Effervescent palate at odds with stewed fruit dark malts. This did not work for me.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: From a 750mL Bottle.  Pours a mostly transparent, hazelnut brown color with a thick layer of frothy beige head.  Aromas of light chocolate, perfumey yeast esters, and bread crusts.  Rather simple and boring, and seems to be missing the yeast and malt complexities found in the standard Brut.  Light bodied, heavily carbonated mouthfeel with a seltzery texture.  Pale chocolate and light bready caramel flavors, spiced by some mild peppery phenols.  Not so interesting, although not bad either.  Warming alcohols in the finish.

A very careful pour produces a seven finger thick, lightly browned, tan colored head that just keeps on growing; it overflows the top of my glass quite a bit.  The beer is a dark brown color, but shows a clear, concentrated red hue when held up to the light.   The aroma is quite inviting as I am inspecting the beer visually; richly caramelized bread notes, toasty grain and dark fruit aromas are all noticeable.  A closer inspection of the nose reveals additional aromatics of green apples, raisins, a green-spicy-herbal note, cocoa, and warming alcohol (enough so I can feel it at times in my nose).  This is interesting as it has the fruit character of a dry Belgian Tripel, but has some dusty, dark malt aromatics thrown in.  The aroma just doesnt have a depth to it that I would like though it is nice.

The beer has sat for some time in my glass with lots of time to lose the voluminous carbonation.  At this point it tastes quite creamy and a bit sweeter than I was expecting.  The beer was served at 50°F (10°C), so a bit warm for the amount of carbonation, but it is quite open in its flavor profile.  Sweet flavors of chocolate flavored caramel, rum soaked raisins, The beer finishes with an appetizing, fermentation derived, spiciness and a dark malt bitterness; flavors reminiscent of white pepper, ginger, clove, bitter chocolate and a touch of espresso all add to a slightly astringent, biting finish.  At times the alcohol is quite noticeable in the finish, really even hot, which is not unexpected in a beer with such a, relatively, light body and of this strength.  I like that this beer is so light for a beer of this strength.  If it wasnt for the alcohol, this would be dangerously drinkable.

This really needs to be a bit more tame on the alcohol front to be really good, sure you could chill the hell out of the beer and that would reduce the alcohol, but you would lose so much of the fruit, malt and spice character then.
Murky chestnut brown.  Light perfume nose with hints of chocolate.  Spritzy body shows light cocoa notes.  Doesnt seem terribly complex or innovative.  Pushed the concept too far?

This bottle is a "Reserve 2003" and I enjoyed it May 2007 with the ultimate chocolate cake where some of the "healthy" ingredients were 400 grams of 86% chocolate. This bottle have been waiting for such a cake - and it was a perfect match! Its dark brown with chunks of sediment and a huge, creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, sweetness, vanilla, sherry and some chocolate. The mouthfeel is prickly and the flavour has notes of sweetness, candy sugar, vanilla, sherry, roasted malt, chocolate, figs and other dark fruits. It was a nice experience in it self and with the cake! 2061

750ml bottle. Muted aroma: damp, earthy yeast, semisweet malt and rubber. Pours muddy brown with dark copper highlights with a big, creamy brown head. Firm body with good carbonation. Yeast, banana, bitter chocolate, bread dough, raisins on the tongue. Not as complex as I had hoped. I much preferred the Brut Reserve to this.

Appearance: Kaboom goes the cork! Pours a cloudy, dark brown body with a fizzy, medium-sized off-white head.

Smell: Earthy, yeast-drenched aroma with notes of chocolate, dark malts, and lemon.

Taste: Chocolatey taste with a subdued sweetness buts up against a sour, lemony taste. Faint, berrylike fruitiness. Earthy, spicy yeast character. Theres a little tartness in the drying finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Spritzy carbonation. Warming alcohol presence.

Drinkability: An interesting mix of flavors, but, in all honesty, I preferred the Brut Reserve.

Good to try this in conjunction with the straight brut reserve.  Has a very similar funkiness.  A little more body to this one with the faint chocolate malt added.  Cloudy brown color with a big fizzy tan head.  Smooth caramel aroma that faintly comes through to the flavor.

750ml bottle, thanks to holdenn for this generous sample. pours auburn with a creamy tan head. nose of red and dark fruits, a bit doughy. flavors of dark fruits, dough, yeasty, plums, and raisins. alcohol is well hidden. full mouth feel. smooth finish. pretty tasty stuff.

Bottle labeled 30/06/2008 thanks to a trade with john_adam.  Pours a dark auburn brown black with a beige head.  Nose is light a little red fruit and dough.  Dark fruit flavors are strong but they slowly rescind to undertones of bread, mocha, yeast and a creaminess that dries out.  Overcarbonated but a nice medium full mouthfeel.  I really enjoyed this one.

Bottle from the First Houston TastingPours an average brown, like the shade of a late autumn leaf.  Aroma of bready malt with a slight alcohol tinge.  Flavor is candied malt with a slice of sweet bread.  Full mouthfeel.  Niiiice beer.

muddy brown, fine dirty white head, bitts of drippy lace,

750. Thanks, hogfodder! Im going to have to try this again, much earlier in the evening, before my tastebuds have been shredded by lesser beers. Pours clear dark brown with a tan head. Lightly sweet flavor, with a bittersweet finish. Any more definition is going to have to wait for a second tasting.

Bottle courtesy of eaglefan538, thanks again Brian! Dark red pour with a light tan head. Aroma of yeast, chocolate, sweet malt and dark fruits. Flavors of chocolate, liquorice, yeast, booze, dark fruits. Medium body w/ big carbonation dry/spicy with a sweet finish. Nice.

First Official Houston Tasting. Thanks to Kaggie97 for bringing this. Nice brown color with nice white head. Nose is nice sugary malts with some dark fruits. Flavor is bready fruits (dark) with sweet flavors.

Pours a cloudy amber brown, with a medium off white head.  Smells pretty earthy, some yeast, dark fruits, and light maltiness.  The flavor is very sugary sweet, alot of dark fruits, maybe a touch of some cinnamon.  Nice little dessert brew I think.  Alot of Belgian candy sugar in the flavor as well, kind of spritzy, reminiscent of champagne.  This was a tasty little treat.
Dark brown, small head dissipate completely, nice lacing. Aroma is fizzy, alcohol, caramel. Taste is alcohol, molasses, lingering pine bitterness. Full mouthfeel but fizzy.

Malheurs yeast is so strongly peppery its amazing. The foam(!) is peppery (although less on the Noir than on the regular Brut). Body stays thin not just from the alcohol but from the crazy Malheur effervescence. Just a touch of brown sugar and molasses flavors to go with the spicy pepper and anise notes, really rounded out compared to the regular Brut. Nice but not savagely spicy as in the Brut Reserve.

text: Bottle. 2003 Vintage. Rich mahogony color with a nice tan head. Tart, rich caramel, spicy aroma. Rich malt, slight chocolate flavor with yeast and spice and a bit of dusty earth. Medium body. Very carbonated. Lingering cocoa and spice. Very slight warming from alcohol. Dry finish.

750 ML bottle, MJs Rare Beer Club Vintage 2003 9/1/07:  Mohogany brown w/ a lasting, huge, mousse like beige head.  The 2 years Ive had it in my refrigerator may have helped the clarity.  Spicy, peppery yeast is very strong.  Some anise notes, wood bark, and dusty and bready malts.  Also has hints of vanilla, chocolate, and dried pitted fruites (apricots) as well as some spicy alcohol notes.  Dry, well balanced to lightly bitter.  Bready malt is light and has hints of chocolate and herbal hops with just a hint of plum fruitiness.  Overall very subtle, maybe just a bit too subtle for me as bitterness and herbal hop win out in the dry lingering finish and aftertaste.  Highly carbonated, smooth, then dries out as it leaves the mouth from alcohol.  Lighter medium body, and warming alcohol.  Just a bit too bitter for my palate!  It would also be interesting to see how it would pair with food since the complexity is very subtle.

At over $25 a bottle, it wont be frequenting my cellar or my shelf, which is too bad. This is an excellent Biere Brut. 
Incredibly complex nose, with sherry, vanilla, and fine wood all showing up.
Oak dry taste with some coffee notes. 
Balanced bitterness with alcohol zest and oak.

Bottle, 75 cl. Reserve 2003. Brown and hazy. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and spices. Complex and well balanced between sweetness and bitterness. Dry. Full body, sticky texture. Alcohol in the finish. Very good beer.

Sample, at the Mondial de la bière, savoured June 2 2006; eye: dark burgundy with golden reflections, no head, no effervescence; nose: coriander, liquorice, molasses, caramel, roasting; mouth: coriander, black liquorice, caramel, roasting, pepper, enjoyable finale in caramel-alcohol, quite carbonated, full body

FRANÇAIS 

Échantillon, bue au Mondial de la bière, savourée le 2 juin 2006; oeil : bourgogne foncé avec reflets dorés, pas de mousse, pas deffervescence; nez : coriandre, réglisse, mélasse, caramel, torréfaction; bouche : coriandre, réglisse noire, caramel, torréfaction, poivre, finale caramel-alcool agréable, très carbonatée, corsée

Pours dark brown with small head. The sweet malty aroma is packed with chocolate, toffee and overripe fruits. Sweet and complex flavor with notes of raisins, dates, plums and chocolate.  Finishes with nice warming alcohol and rather dry for a beer of this type. Lovely!
Sampled at the Newtown Brewfest 07 with Stegosaurus. Dark amber pour with a roasty alcohol aroma. Spicy dry roast flavor with possible fruity undertones. I liked it alot.
Dark brown with off-white head.  Dark fruits, yeast, and malt on the nose.  The spiciness stood out in the caramel body with good yeast bite.

Pours a nice burnt amber color with a nice light tan head.  Very powerful sweet ripe fruit, spicy yeast, good caramel on the nose.  Very full highly carbonated outhfeel with a good dose of caramel, raisens, spicy yeastiness, and a good dose of a floral like hoppiness.  A fantastic beer that is very deserving of the rating!

text: Ive been saving this puppy for a special occasion and got some great news today at a morning meeting so out pops the cork. The aroma was earthy and lightly spicy through a dense deep tan head with caramel and fruit. The fruit presence was dark fruits of raisin and prune with a musty cellar presence. The effervescent beer was clear deep brown in the St. Bernardus chalice.  The flavor was deep and mysterious with dark fruits, raisins and prunes, and an earthy and lightly spicy flavor coming along for the ride. The spice presence contained a hint of cinnamon and a bit of clove with peppery leading the charge toward home. Also in the meld was a bit of smooth chocolate and a hint of roast. The body was medium full and the carbonation level was high leading to a creaminess on the palate. The beer was unique, interesting, and just what the Doctored ordered for celebration of the day. 750 ml corked and bailed bottle. $22.99 at Brawleys in Charlotte. Best beofre end 30/062008.

text: 750 bought at Sams. This one was a bit pricey at $22, and I sort of regret buying it but oh well. Shared with Taylor and a nice bowl of northern lights on 9/16/07. Nose is very nice--a bit of tart fruit, some caramel, cocoa and spices. Slightly vinous. Flavor seems a bit subdued when compared to the vibrant and complex nose. Some belgian spices, a little cocoa, and some raisin. Alcohol is very well hidden. A good beer but like all $20 750s, I expected a little more.
dark copper color.  aroma is fruity, also new vinyl and raisiny malt.  flavor is a little metallic and tangy, but quickly goes to raisiny malt and a bit hot.  leafy bitter finish.

750 ml bottle @ Falling Rock poured a clear brown with a large lasting tan head. Aromas of carmel, toffee, spice, dark fruit and light yeast. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp. Flavors of cocoa, toffeee and light spice with a crisp malty finish.
Black of color with a beige head. An aroma of spice, dark fruits and notes of sweet liqurice. A flavor of sweet liqurice, some spice, sweet notes and a bitter finish.

750mL bottle  on 22AUG07.  Dark Brut it is!  Dark brown.  Aroma of sweetness, raisins.  Flavors of rich malt, dark fruits.  High Alcohol!  Finishes llike a Dubbel, just a little bit stronger,  And Better!

Pour was a copperish color with big head and good lacing.  Aroma was of fruits yeast.  Flavor was fruits malts chocolate and some bitter/hops to balance it out.  This one is a great beer, thanks eagle.

Jimmack shared this at Mullmans gathering.  Very dark brown in color with a big tan head and lively carbonation.  Aroma seemed a bit muted at first when cold but opened up once it started warming up a bit.  chocolate, dark fruits, musty yeast, and some aromatic malts in the aroma.  Taste: chocolate, musty belgian yeast, dark fruits, lightly bready, earthy...with light caramel.  Finishes earthy and spicy.  Carbonation very lively but not too sharp.

dark brown with very nice lacing and a large foamy light tan head.  aroma consists of light licorice, dark malt, sugar, and yeast.  flavor has notes of big time vanilla, almond extract, licorice, herbs, earthy dark malts.  wonderful, unique flavors.  awesome beer.

Pour was beautiful, tons of light tan head on each pour, wonderful hazed copper color/body, great lacing, completely effervescent. The aroma was dried fruits, dark malts, some yeast. The flavor was excellent, dried fruits, dark Munich type malts (choco, nuts, light breadiness), finishing with a significant dryness, very light malt sweetness, and balancing bitterness perhaps from yeast and some light hopping. Not a runaway sweet Belgian style beer at all. The body is moderate to full, plenty carbonated. This is probably my favorite of the champagne beers Ive had so far (Malhuer blonde, Lust, Deus).

From a 750ml dark green bottle labeled Dark Chocolate Reserve 2003. Bubbles forth from the bottle but does not sustain any head. Deep mahoganny color with very fine bubbles and a vicsous alcoholic lace. Slight raisny aroma. Smooth mouthfeel, big body with a slightly dry finish, hint of chocolate, and alcoholic warming. Effervescent like the basic Malheur. Neck booklet even includes a multi-lingual recipie for chocolate souffle.
Aroma is of dark fruity maltiness. Flavor was really smooth and bubbly. Pretty tastey overall. Pretty dry overall and had a little roastiness to it.
750ml bottle from rare beer club. One of the most amazing beers I have tried. Tastes like your deinking candy. Ive got some of this aging at my house. Mmmmmmm.
