750ml bottle from Columbus Tasting 8 - Pours dark brown with a big tan head.  Aromas of candi sugar, toasted malts, caramel, and some yeast.  Flavor is Candi sugar, caramel, toasted malts with some slight hops at the finish.  Palate was quite fizzy.  Much like a bottle of champagne.  Dry finish.  Not too bad.
C-Bus 8 - Bottle shared by nolankowal: Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma, roasted malts, fruity, some yeasty notes. Flavor, roasty, yeasty, some chocolate, and some dark fruits. Pretty good.

(Bottle) Pours deep dark red. Yeasty, vinous and light spicy aroma with notes of grapes and chocolate. Fruits like pears and apples are also present. A bit grassy and oily. Yeasty and malty flavour with a spicy backdrop. Some fruity tones with hint of dark fruit in the background. Sharp carbonation. Too sweet and a bit too much alcohol. Medium, champagne like body.
Nice twist on the Malheur Brut with some chocolate additions. Subtle chocolate notes blended very nicely with a great strong ale. Nice floral notes and rich dark malt prevails.
Bottle. Dark brown coloured with a rather large offwhite head.  Malty and sweet with notes of chocolate, spices, yeast, hops and coffee.

Bottled. 
Very dark mahogany colour. Pretty complex flavour profile, yet lighter and not so pronounced. Very champagne-like, fizzy mouthfeel that adds freshness with lots of sugar along with chocolate notes. A subtle, refined beer, not meant for rough palates like mine. The 12% does not give this beer the power it ought to have.
darker brown coloured body with a medium off white head  roasted coffee aroma and a roasted coffee and chocolat taste and a bitter roasted coffee and alcohol finich
Bottle:(Tanx to Ekstedt) Dark red colour,,nice head. Aroma of,spicy,yeasty,dust,and hopy nose. Flavor almost the same,nice full body, and a long coplexy finish.

Bottle. Dark clear reddish brown, large beige fluffy head. Roasted toffeish malt aroma with woody spicy and yeasty notes, and a clear touch of alcohol. Medium bodied, very smooth mouthfeel. A bit sweet, still with a long and dry finish. Felt a bit restrained in the aromas, maybe some years of cellaring will do good.

dark brown with some amber in there. nice caramel head. dark fruit aromas with some yeasty goodness. champagne yeast upfron. raisons and plums wth nice chocolate throughout. well balanced. love the fizzyness of it and the prickle on the tongue from the bubbles. alcohol is well hidden. enjoyable and fun.

Bottle at Hopleaf, BB 6/30/08.  Poured a deep garnety-brown with a short beige head.. rising carbonation never lets the head completely settle.  Aroma picked up deep vinous notes and heavy woody accents (vanilla and lightly-charred oak star).. sweet and eminently enjoyable caramel across the middle with the vinous returning for the finish.  Flavor found deep caramel and vinous notes again with some spicy yeast.. sweet with moderate herbal bitterness.. when the bubbles pop in your mouth, the flavors let loose.. warm and tasty!  Creamy, sweet, and spritzy on the palate with little alcohol apparent.. excellent feel and flow to it.
Bottle at KØ07. Buttery, hoppy aroma. Dark brown colour. Small bubbly head. Peppery and malty flavour, as expected. Quite strong on the alcohol, a bit too much for me.

750ml. bottle. Having had the Biere Brut Reserve many times and loving it, I was highly anticipating this one. Dark brown with red highlights and a big sudsy beige head. Fruity, yeasty aroma with some wine-like qualities. Flavor starts of semi-sweet, with lots of dark dried fruits, dark chocolate and pumpernickel bread. Turns much drier at the end, with a nice warming alcoholic finish. Excellent!

Pours brown with a beige head. Quite sweet. Strong residual sweetness. Strong fruityness of dark dried fruits like prunes and raisins. Medium and kinda fine carbonation. Very full bodied. Sweet finish. Good stuff.

Thanks to Jimmack for sharing at Joeec5’s party. Pours a nice deep dark brown with a fluffy spritzy foamy off white head- similar to a rochefort look.  Aroma is light champagne, chocolate malts, white wine character, belgian yeast, and a bit of dough.  More chocolate malt flavors, but with a champagne character, fruity esters, white grape, and a mild bitter finish.  Spritzy high carbonation yet smooth mouthfeel.  Reminde dme fo Rochefort a bit, but with a champagne touch to it.  Unique and very nice.

Bottle. Dark with beige head. Aroma of malts and citrus combined with cellar, dust, yeast, brown sugar and some raisin. Flavour of brown sugar, malt, lime crest. Slightlysour, slightly bitter, slightly dusty. Delicious beer

Bottle sampled (expensive). Pours cola brown with a fluffy khaki colored head. Aroma of chocolate, roast, caramel, belgian spices, and belgian yeast. The flavor is sweet, chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, smooth, and fruit. Good healthy body, moderate carbonation. Great brew.

Sampled at stateline belgium night. Pours a dark brown color with a decent tan head. Aroma of toasted malts, caramel, light dark fruits, and raisins. Flavor of caramel, dried fruits, some roast and some spices with a warming alcoholic finish

Deep brown, with a good head and good perlage.
Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts, caramel.
Palate: Chocolate, yeast, spiced, rosted malts.

Cloudy, deep coke brown with orange like hues. Wispy head and lace. Nose of caramel, anise, farmy belgium yeast, hint of chocolate, spices and others. Medium bodied, moderately fizzy carbonation, lush, malty, begium sugar, chocolate, caramel, boozy alcohol but in a enjoyable way, bit of banana. Dry, grassy finish, warming. Very nice Belgium strong, think I paid a bit much for but a damn good brew. Drinkablility is insane for a 12% brew.
Great stuff here.  pours a dark brown. tons of bubbles, like champagne.  Taste is belgian through and through.  Its pricy but damn its good.

Medium sized light brown head, retention is fair with a goodly amount of lace hanging around. Dark brown color, clear. Nose is chocolatey, light caramel, lightly fruity, some bananna? Body is medium, well carbonated, almost spritsy, lightly coating, oily. Chocolatey flavors up front, cocoa, caramel over ripe bananna, yeasty with a hint of berries. Finish is almost dry, chocolatey and a hint roasty. Interesting to say the least. Enjoyed at State Lines Belgian tasting on 4/14/07 Thanks Roberrrrt!
Belgian beer festival Brussels 2006:  quite nice, very flavorful, top notch...want it again

75 cL champagne bottle. Pours deep amber with light offwhite head. Arom is yeasty, chocolate and hops. Full bodied and slight creamy feel. Flavour is sweet, subdued hops bitterness followed by a complex chocolate based bitterness palate. Lingers chocolately into the finish, a touch of alcohol reaches the nose in the finish. I had this at home for desert with a chocolate mousse, which I can only recommend :)

(Bottle) Dark reddish brown, copper-like colour with huge beige head, that sinks away after a while, leaving very little lacing. Lots of sediment in the bottom of the bottle. Huge, complex nose with a distinct champagne-like yeast aroma, notes of chocolate, dark rye bread, hints of smoke, citrussy hops and loads of spices and herbs (thyme, marjoram, rosemary and a slight hint of lavender). Spicy, malty taste with notes of chocolate, coffee, dark rye bread, roasted nuts and moccha. Thyme and rosemary coming through in the middle, giving away for a punch of alcohol towards the chocolatey finish with distinct notes of coffee liqueur (Kahlua or Tia Maria). Very potent, but still very soft, spicy and complex. Probably a bit sweeter than the blond and lacking some of the massive punch of its blond sister. Still: awesome, beautiful and brilliant!

Tasted 2007-03-24. 4 years old bottle, 75 cl. Very dark red/brown colour with a reddish head. Aroma of nuts, alcohol, fruits and burned sugar. Fruity taste of burned sugar, nuts and hops. Vey hoppy indeed considering the age.

750 ml Bottle. Dark brown body with a brown head. Aroma is complex, malt, sugar, alcohol, yeast, caramel, dry fruit and a little roasted. Flavor has some of the same. Sweet malt, caramel, dry fruit, yeast, alcohol, chocolate, coffee and overripe sweet cherries. A complex and delicious experience.
Nice dark deep color poured from the bottle.Nice roasted chocately flavors without a tremendous amount of complexity. Nice.

Hmmm.  Highly recommended by  the server, but not my favorite as first tasted, but the flavor quickly mellowed for further tastes.  Probably best drank at a slightly warmer temperature and some aging.  Have to try again. Tried it at the12 hour Belgian beer partyin Carlsbad, CA.  Possibly the best beer tasting ever,with 70 bottled rare and expensive beers and 20 on draft.

Malheur tasting at the Monks Café in Philly.  Poured from a 750 ml bottle.  Clear brown with a tan head.  Yeasty with light caramel, chocolate and spice.  Dryish, champagne-like cocoa powder, dark fruits with some mildly sour barnyard notes.  Kind of like a St. B Abt 12 light.

Darker brown coloured with some light carbonation and a medium off-white head. Roasted chocolat-coffee aroma with some hints of wood and sherry. Full palate, some sprankling. Finish is strong, bitter roasted, with some touches of coffee and alcohol. Special one.
Intens brown almost black and with a fine but quick disappearing head. Very nutty taste with almonds and caramel. Touch of coffee, malt and liqurice. Finishes with a fine balanced bitterness.

Bottle. Near opaque dark brown colour with a large beige head. Aroma of toasted malt, chocolate, caramel, hint of greenish, woody almost sour fruit and brown sugar. Flavour of chocolate, toasted malts, caramel,  a nice bitterness, raisins, some sweetness, spices and alcohol. Full bodied, moderate carbonation. Very good.

Provided by my cousin for an after-dinner sampling on Christmas Day; i believe he purchased it from belgianshop. 
Poured a dark cola color. Flavors of chocoloate, cherries, and roasted malt, with a bit of an herbal or medicinal flavor. Full bodied and effervescent. very tasty. Thanks, Ed!

Bottle. Tasting 12-01-2007 (Søren, Peter, Carsten). Huge fizzy off-white head that diminished so fast. Never seen anything disappear so quickly. Lacing was spare, if not none excising. Body was clear and sparkling with a ruby like color. Aroma was very complex with notes of cookie, molasses, caramel, chocolate, coffee, nutty, leather, bubble gum, raisin, date and brown sugar. Full bodied with an oily texture and an average carbonation. Moderated sweet with some balancing bitter flavor. Great experience I thought and again one of evenings highlights.

2004 Bottle - Dark brown body, red shine, thick beige head, thick lacing; Very balanced chocolate malty, green hoppy fresh nose; Very light fresh and full sparkle, balanced bitter, soft texture; Long spicy finish, alcohol shows, carbonation bites a bit, lots of aroma chocolate and spices.

(750ml bottle, 2003 vintage)  Pours a dark brown body with a medium-sized creamy beige head.  Aroma of lightly toasted malt, caramel, plums, vanilla, wood, and sherry.  Flavor of raisins, brown sugar, toasted marshmallow, mild hops, and oak with a soft mouthfeel and dry finish.  Nice complexity.
Botle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Taste is sweet with malts and dark fruit.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2007 Pours out a radiant brown with Oaked Yeti-like tan head, beautiful. Aroma is penetrating and inviting at the same time - chocloate, vanilla beans, fruit filled scones, caramel, licorice, cherries and blueberries. Flavor is more of the same, mainly focused on the chocolate and cherries, leading into the alcohol dancing all over my tongue and down the back of my throat. Palate was so rich I didnt want to swallow, just hold it there and breathe in the chocolate covered fruit aromas. Finish was elegant and deceptively smooth, alcohol created warmth but no real burn. Awesome beer.

Bottle @ Kerstbierfestival 2006 in Essen, BE. Dark brown color with a fair off-white head. Aroma is malty, roasted, wood, vanilla, nuts, coffe, chocolate. Flavor is heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration. finish is moderate alcoholic.

Bottle at Kerstbierfestival 200, Essen. Dark brown with a healthy tan head. Vanilla, chocolate and fruit aromas. dry bitter chocolate flavours, warming alcohol, creamy mouthfeel, dry woody finish. A world-class beer.

From bottle at Kerstbierfestival. Dark, dark brown, ultra-creamy head. Malty, hoppy, coffee aroma with chocolate notes. Sweetness balanced with dark malt, hops -- but not sufficiently for my taste. Still, very special.
Bottle: Poured a dark brown with a creamy off white head. Sweet wood and fruit like aroma. Rich dark nutty chocolate that changed to a zippy dry finish.
Dark Brown Coloring with Sandy Ring.  Heavy Rich, Red Fruit..Strawberries...Heavy Warming.  Has a Bittersweet Lambic Twang to it.  Dry and Yeasty...Sweet Bread Dough Beginning...  Very Nice

Poured a hazy brown color with a medium tan head.  The aroma was "dry" and tart with notes of chocolate and mint.  The flavor was sweet and malty with chocolate and some fruitness.  Lively mouthfeel and warming in the chest.
Bottle, 75 cl. Dark red colour, frothy beige head. Slightly vinuos aroma with apples and spices. Spicy aroma with a sourish finish. Full-bodied, and with hints of alcohol.
Bottle, 750 ml. Deep brown/red. Clear. Really good head from huge carbonation. Immense aroma and flavour, great!! Sparkling and dry, cant detect the 12%.

This dark brown ale poured with a nice beige head, eliciting a chocolate aroma. The flavor is of chocolate and plums,  and a large swallow leaves a warm alcohol trace from the mouth to the belly.  A perfect complement to Belgian chocolates.

Pours extremely dark with deep orange when held to light. Huge grey head thats very active and continues to foam up after pouring. The aroma is mostly alcoholic, yeasty and quite spicy. To taste this is quite sweet but also a touch thin? alcohol burn, musty character and a touch metallic. Overall this is easy drinking, powerful and strong, interesting but not outstanding.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2006 75 cl. bottle. Dark color with a creamy some brownish head that lingers for a good while. Aroma of chocolate, dried plums and spices. Body lighter than I expected. Taste of chocolate, champagne mouthfeel, Jerez wine, some honey. After a while it leaves a brandy feeling. Not the best of the Malheur, imo.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2008 Sampled at Mondial 2006. A dark brown color with some amber. The head is khaki. The aroma had apples with some cherries. There was also some alcoholic brnady type character. The taste is alsocoholic with brandy, pears and some smooth cinnamon spice in teh finish. The body was well put together. Tried this agian recently thanks to general_gao. I didnt like it as much as it was fairly simplistic with pancakes and walnuts. I averaged my two ratings.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2008 Pepsi-like color with a Pepsi-like head.  Vinous, dried dark fruits (raisins, blueberries), earthy.  Soft carbonation.  Heavy and filling.  Surprisingly little initial alcohol feeling for such a high abv and this makes you wanna go for big sips.  But thats a ruse, the 12% really shows up in the finish for a warming alcohol feeling along with the regret of not taking smaller sips.  Belgian Strong with a barley wine attitude.  Loved it.

Sampled at the mondial 06, dark brown color, with a frothy beige head, leaving nice laces, soft chocolate and caramelized malts, chocolatey praline accent, hint of vanilla, with fruity notes of plums, raisins, dates, and molasses in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a sweet caramelized malt character, with raisins, plums fruitiness, chocolatey accent, a warming accent, hint of spiciness, brown sugar, molasses, nutmeg leading towards a cacao powder-chocolate milkshake, and a warming alcoholic finish.

Bottle, 2003 and served in my Duval snifter: Pours a muddy brown with ruby hued highlight around the edge, topped by an initial huge frothy beige head and good lace. The aroma has notes of rich plum, fig, elderberry, anise, cardamom, coriander, bitter bakers chocolate, roasted malt, woody esters and some alcoholic vapors.  The taste is shocking sweet and fruity at first before a dash of spice and even a bit of barnyard funk cleans up the palate. The alcohol luckily is not as strong as first noted on the nose. The finish is bittersweet and roasty, more like a truffle than a candy bar. Additionally, I discovered some smoked walnut like component which was neato. The mouth feel is rich and warming but does display a touch of chalky finish which kept it from being a 5.  I so want to give this a higher overall rating because the experience was very enjoyable, but alas it did not blow my mind like others in the genre of Dark Belgian Ales.

Bottled (Reserva 2003). Dark brown in colour. Rich beige head lacings. The aroma is fruity with caramel and chocolate. The flavour is A taste of an alcoholic sensation strikes thru Malt and caramel in the flavour as well.
Bottled. Hazy brown colour, big brownish head. Huge apple, alcohol and dark chocolate. Flavour has caramel, dark chocolate, alcohol and dried fruits. Very pleasasant mix and wellbalanced flavour.
Brown with a big, tan head, Aroma is both milky and chocolate. There are some dried fruits of plum, chocolate before they strangely go away as it warms. Heady brew fo sure.

MN Winter Get Together, 2006. Bottle. Lambic sourness in the nose; unique aroma. After corking, it wouldnt stop overflowing foam. Excellent lace. Sediment. Dark brown, yellow on edges. Flavor isnt sour. Saffron or allspice. Really nice; reminds me of the Family Farm in Woodside, CA.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 Bottled, 75cl. Dark brown with a large beige head. Aroma has malt, caramel, hops and some alcohol notes. Quite a lot of caramel and malt in the flavor. Lots of alcohol, but nice. Rating: 8-4-8-4-16-4. (060328)Bottle, 75cl. It pours an unclear, brown body with floaties and a big, beige head. Very nice aroma, but hard to pin. Caramel, dried fruits and spicy hints are easy to find, and also some alcohol, but the rest seems to blend into unrecognisability in the typical Belgian way. The flavor is sweet and fruity, with more dried fruits than fresh fruits, a good dash of sugar, some caramel and chocolate, cellar and spices. A subtle bitterness also steps forward. Lots of carbonation, full-bodied and almost sticky mouthfeel. Smooth as hell, and slightly warming. Some bitterness in the finish. Dangerously easy to drink. Well, its not exactly a beer one can down several bottles of, but is sure slides down easily. (081108)

Clear, brilliant red with nice, underlying brown hues.  Sweet, chocolatey aroma with an interesting blend of sweet caramel, nuts, cocoa powder, pilsner malt, noble hops, light cherry, vanilla, whole grains, plums, licorice, mild alcohol and some light roasted notes.  The body is light and fairly robust with a nice, prickly carbonation than really explodes in the mouth.  The flavor is sweet, but dry; a really perplexing profile that is hard to explain.  It starts sweet, promoting the dark fruit, cocoa, caramel, brown sugar and alcohol.  Toward the end, more tropical fruity esters come out and mix with the somewhat potent hop blend (grasses, light pine) producing a dry, warming finish.  This is a really interesting beer with a unique profile and complex interweavings of flavors and aromas.  Tasty and enjoyable, but something is a little off that kept my enjoyment lower than I would have expected.  I will say, drinking this with dark chocolate increases the enjoyment far more than I ever expected.  Youre well advised to enjoy this with a tasty chocolate dessert!

Poured a reddish brown color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of chocolate, caramel malts, nuts, light dark fruits, and some alcohol as well.  Taste of light cocoa, some roast, caramel malts, nuts, and alcohol as well.

The beer looks beautiful in the glass. It has a huge frothy head with a slight tan hue whichs fades into a nice covering of small bubbles. The beer does not have a strong aroma with hints of roasted and darker malts and some dried fruits. The body is excellent with a light to medium feel in the mouth and tons of bubbles, the carbonation is very high. The flavor has hints of chocolate and malt with some of the same dried fruits almost like a sherry or port. The dominant flavor is from the belgian yeast strain and is the first thing you can detect. The other flavors are more underlying. The alcohol is slightly present with an appropriate amount of warming but not overwhelming. The finish is quite dry and overall the beer is very drinkable and nice. I just feel the import version labeled "Black Chocolate" is not an appropriate name as you would expect alot more roasted and chocolatey character. Knowing the original name "Dark Brut" makes me think this is a much better beer than I had first thought.

2003 bottle.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Not as heavily carbonated as the regular brut.  Smells oakey with figs, some plums and raisins popping out.  Tastes of biscuits with chocolate, coffee beans, some alcohol and whiskey notes.  Some fruity notes on the finish.  Good, but the regular brut is much better.

75 cL bottle, Black Chocolate version, Reserve 2003 (sampled February 2006): Extremely loud and explosive cork removal.  Thick, frothy light cocoa colored head quickly diminishes into a thin, dark brown film with loads of small bubbles.  Deep, outrageously rich and complex aroma.  Dusty cocoa powder and light alcohol combine with toasty dark bread notes in the background, while soft flower petals and butter soaked almonds mix with herbal esters and thick raisiny malts.  Well textured palate  balanced between super tingly, slightly gritty while being velvety smooth.  A peppery, chocolate spice hits the tip of the tongue, while the tropical fruitiness jumps between papaya and mango.  Dark, smooth chocolate truffles with a lightly sweet raspberry essence and soft brett notestruly a remarkable beer with a depth of flavour matched by but a few

First thing that struck me was that this was more like a sour brown ale vs a Belgian Strong.The nose was weird inthat I did not detect the normal spice and dark fruit I was expecting. The taste was different tho and was full of sweet malts but there was some kind of underlying sour tongue numbing action going on.Very complex brew.
MN Winter Get Together, 2006:  Color of mud with no head.  Bready malt aroma with what struck me as cherry.  Bone dry malt taste and a slight sourness that I believe is still cherry.  Solid!
Very good in its own style and as beer overall.  Sweet malt and fruit aromas.  More sweet malt in the flavor but less fruit.  Dark and nearly opaque, anlmost like a quad.

Light fruit aroma. Somewhat light body with ripened fruit taste. Mostly banana with what reminds me of those chocolate covered cherry candies. Good mix of flavours, and well balanced with a drying finish.

Thanks Cquiroga!  Pours a slightly hazy dark/medium brown color with a small off-white head and sticky lacing.  Aroma is malty and sweet with cherry and chocolate hints.  Flavor is like bananas with hints of malt, nuts and a slight note of alcohol in the finish.  Very smooth and slightly dry at the end.

2003 reserve. Beautiful dark appearance. BIG puffy tan head that lasted the entire drink. Licorice, honey, wine-like after taste. Little alcohol in the finish too. Great interesting beer. 12% is not to be fooled with at all.

Courtesy of Tom at Monks Cafe.

I forgot to write down the vintage, but the bottle looked quite old as the ripped label was showing lots of signs of aging. Aroma is heavy with chocolate malts and Belgian yeasty notes. Hints of dark fruit as well. Crimson hued brown/black color with a frothy tan head. Very concentrated chocolate malt flavors in the fore followed by a hint of raisin and cherry sweetness and leading into a slightly dry and funky finish. The chocolate and dark fruit flavors linger nicely in the aftertaste.

2003 bottle. Dark reddish brown, hazy with a thick off white to moka head. Nice horseblanket lambic aroma, coniferous, ground cherry notes, complex. Rich hoppy malt, resinous, with grapefruit, an hybrid between a gueuze and an old ale. Excellent. Merci Mike. Shared with Chris, and Mike, November, 2005.

Bottle. Dark brown colour. Tan coloured head. Fruity aroma with hints of yeast and chocolate. Sweet flavour and a little fruity. Hints of yeast and dark chocolate.
Warming alcohol in the finish. A very lovely beer.

Bottled.
Dark amber, short beige head.
Spicy in both aroma and flavour; cedar-tree.
Sweet and champagne-ish in the mouth.
Warm alco-feel; vinous.

bottle. deep brown with a slight red tinge to it and a large fluffy brownish head. the aroma is awesome - tart cherry and various fruits along with a funky character to it. soft earthy malt notes too. huge complex body with flavours of tart cherry and hefty dark chocolate. the alcohol level was quite warm but pleasantly balanced. fantastic.
Robe brune aux reflets rouges surmontée dune mousse blanche qui sestompe. Arômes de sucre, dépices et de blé. Saveurs de malt, de levure, dépices et de cassonade.

[750 ml bottle, 12.0c, exp: 15/12/2006]
Tasted with the guys from Institut de la Bière.

Dark/burgundy appearance. Dense white head. Fruity, sweet chocolate. Carbonation, medium-bodied. Warming alcohol. spicy brown sugar sweetness. Alcohol hits at finish. Very pleasing experience. A must!

Very nice soft roasted malt and chocolate/caramel characters, with a typical Belgian twist (yeast, estery fruit). Quite soft, with a warming finish. [bottle at Kulminator] Pours very dark brown with a big head. The nose has lots of dark bitter chocolate, yeast, some fruit, prunes, dates. full bodied, dry finish with a little bitterness.
Kulminator, Antwerp 2005: Nice dark brown color with a medium foamy head, leaving a blanket on the glass. Soy souce nose with prunes. Caramel and malt taste, also molasses, slightly sour - nice.

Bottled (BB 12/2006)
Dark ruby color with good tanned head, lace, lively carbonation. Aroma is mainly malty and horse blanket with fruity and lemony notes. Full-bodied, carbonated mouthfeel. Hoppy bitter, alcoholic, fruity - plums, raisins with licorice flavors. Long bitter aftertaste. This is delicious carbonated  quadrupel - beer to enjoy in the front of fireplace.

No#66. I have a feeling that this was aged, but im not sure. Aroma is strange, some feet coming off it, with a decent amount of both malt and hops in there. Taste is malty but has a strange bitter herbal taste going on. Different beer, intresting, but not exactly a serious winner.

Nice amber, offwhite head. Grassy aroma, clove, pine needles, malty and nutty with some almond. Spicy and very hoppy flavor. Very strong without too much alcohol coming through. Spicy hoppy finish with some more alcohol showing.
Pour is dark...100% cola looking...thin dense tan head...smell is faint cocoa, yeast, light raisins...sweet chocolate and earth fruit flavor followed by a bitter alcoholic finish...

UPDATED: APR 12, 2007 Poured into my Chimay glass.
Deep mahogany red. Beige head.
Aroma: Banana, chocolate, alcohol, cloves, some malt, fantastic hops, Seville orange, pears.
Flavour: Almost harsh, bitter, really not sour, some sweetness, a bit mineral.
High carbonation, mighty - almost fluffy.

Later on I have noticed tonnes of exotic ruit and complexity, this is a REALLY good beer.

A Mes rate: 
Bottle @ PBF. Dark, almost black or the deepest deepest red. Thin covering of foam that lasts well. Feels like there is too much carb but its over before it gets annoying. Caramel and coffy with cream. Long almost mango finish. Pretty good stuff.

hazy dark, off white head.  yeasty, doughy, spicy, pruney, and mild cocoa aroma.  flavour has a hint of funk lots of spicy yeast, hints of dark bread, malt and cocoa.  caramel, yeast and anise in the finish.  excellent.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2008 Bottle... RBSG2005... Very dark, clear, burnt orange ale with a large, frothy, beige head. The aroma offers notes of sassafras, caramel, brown sugar, dried plum and chocolate... along with a few other goodies I cant identify. The malty flavor is of caramel, cocoa, fescue, raisins and cola with just a tiny pinch of salt. Medium to full-bodied and fizzy. Finishes up a touch alcoholic and bone dry.

Deep brown-ruby, puffy mocha head.  Nose of light funk, chocolate-cola sweetness, root beer.  Flavor has sweet chocolate, a bit of barnyard, bit of cream de minte in its spiciness.  Quite malty, very interesting stuff.

(750ml bottle, RBSG05) Beige head atop a dark brown body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, chocolate, anise.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, chocolate, anise, some cherry.  Medium-full body.  Yummy!
RBSG 05 Pours a brown color. Aroma of yeast, malt and brown sugar. Flavor of yeast, dark malt and brown sugar.

Bottle - corked and caged. Dark brown body with a fomay efferevescent brown head. Nose is yeasty with dark chocolate, light hops, flowery notes and spice. Taste is dark chocolate, yeast, light sweet malts, some cola notes and light spices. Body is very carbonated and rather light. Some dryness towards the end. Finish is more of the chocolate, sweet malts, light cola, and yeast. Rather enjoyable beer.

Clear copper with a light tan head that lasts for the session. The aroma is sweet soda, nuts, chocolate, and some grass. The flavor is sweet with an interesting mixture of grass and salt, also some root beer. Fizzy but soft sugary sweet medium-full mouthfeel that dries out nicely at the end..

Clear brownish red with a thick beige head. Aroma of barnyard/funk and dark fruits. Flavor has notes fo toasted malt, plum, raisin, earthiness, caramel, brett, chocolate and yeast. Alcohol presence detected in the finish. Medium body with very fizzy carbonation. Overall, very nice beer.
Dark brown. Frothy head that dissipates quite quickly. Malty chocolate aroma. Malty, dry, oaky flavour. The alcohol gives it a harsh finish. A little bit too strong for its own good.

Dark brown with large dissapearing foam. Lively aroma of earth, lemon, chocolate and dark malt. Sparkling flavour of dark malts, pear, oranges and white chocolate. fruity aftertaste with notes of sherry.
Deep reddish colour with a tan head. Dusty aroma with fruity notes. Cobweb and dry earthy flavor with a light fruity sweetness.

Skortila shared this bottle with me and another friend, and im so glad he did! Cloudy brown color, medium brown head. Aroma is exceptionally good, strong black and roasted malt, but also soft notes with vanilla and toffee. White wine, sherry. Taste is full bodied with malty and fruity tones. The brut yeast makes the beer quite dry. Alcohol burn is only slightly present, but it suits the beer perfectly. A newcomer in my personal top10!

Bottle. Aroma has a lot in it, malts (chocolate, toffee), spices (pepper ea), some dark fruits and vanilla. Cloudy, brown coloured with a lasting, medium brown head. Taste is sweet, malty (toffee, chocolate), roasted, some vanilla in it, some fruits, creamy. Sherry-like taste. Very decent bitterness in the finish combined with a complex spicy  (peppery) taste. Quite dry with a decent body. Magnificent brew.
Bottle. Red brown colour with a baige head. Herbal spicy barnyard  aroma and a sweet medicin taste. Medium body and a sweet finish. There is just something I don´t like in this beer.

Bottled at DBF 2005.
Brown coloured with a small beige head.
Spicy and herby aroma with lots of sweetness.
Nice flavour with lots of fruits and herbs.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2005 (Bottle 75 cl) Very dark, almost black with a fine slightly off-white head. Huge almost vulgar champagne-like bubbles. Extremely complex aromas of....I dont really know what - some coffee perhaps. Dry and rather bitter. But an extremely complex flavoural pattern and indeed a unique experience. 190305

Head is initially huge, frothy, off-white, fully lasting.
Body is hazy dark brown, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, toasted grain/bread, coffee), lightly yeasty (horseblanket, barnyard, 
cobwebs), with notes of anise and coriander.

Flavor is heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, velvety texture, lively/fizzy carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Nice aroma, excellent appearance, well-hidden alcohol.  Not as rich and luxurious in the mouth as Id have wanted, but quite nice.

Again, I am grateful to BeanDip and her man for sharing this rare treat with me last night! 

 Poured a dusty brown / black body and a full on rocky khaki colored head. The aroma and flavor were predominantly yeasty to me, but nice notes of toasted chocolate barleys fall in next. Hints of toffee, and lightly sweet brown sugars are next, but there was still a doughyness to be found. You know, it was much like what I think a Belgian style Porter would be like brewed with those peppery cardboard, chalky Belgian yeasts. I think I was expecting more of a sweet chocolaty resemblance to in the beer? Overall, a very well crafted beer. I would love to sample it again one day.
Bottle. Dark brown with lovely dense head. Figs, ginger, liqourice, vinous, alcohol, dry. High carbonation makes the body seem full-ish. A complex and well made beer.

Aroma:Wood,cherry,chocolate....
Appearance:Dark brown huge head...
Flavor:Spicy,alcohol,cherry and wood....
This beer taste sirop for the flu...
UPDATED: MAY 20, 2007 Ruby-brown colored beer with a creamy head. Refreshing beer with some nice flavours. Medium bodied ale, with fruity undertones, full of alcohol and chocolate.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2011 2010-08-11, bottle at RisRas, Århus, bb 05/2010, 8-5-8-4-17=42Dark brown color; medium sized head. Nice, mild aroma of chocolate, Belgian yeast, cork, spices. Good body strength; spicy chocolate flavor, pleasant residual sweetness. The bitterness is not very high. Warming alcohol. Very enjoyable.2004-12-11, 10-5-8-5-18=46Dark color; nice head. Very complex aroma, with a base of banana and much more (spices? Chocolate? Herbs? Mint? ). High carbonation, but still good malt and strong bitterness.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2008 The Lure:Frothy dark chocolate explodes from the bottle upon decorking. Minty green wood roams shyly atop the big bubbles. The aroma is nice, but it does not fully announce the immense pleasure to be had upon tasting.

The Festivities:Diplomatic roastiness hires a few prunes, furtive cherries and looming black grapes to garnish the walls of the ballroom. Elegantly decorated with shining yet dry wooden floors and minty leaves, this will be the setting for a smooth bubble ballet where champagne alcohol will splash around like well-controlled confetti. All is done with finesse, silk gloves, platters of dark chocolate and a few sticks of licorice.

Transcendence:Ornate stalagtites and stalagmites adorn a quiet but impressive cavern.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2006 (Bottled, 0.75l, Reserve 2003, re-rate - changed aroma from 9 to 8) Very dark reddish brown color with a largeish, beige head. Very malty, very caramely aroma, that turns sourish, port-wineous, berryish and imperial-stoutish when warm. Some alcohol in the aroma. Very smoothly malty, port-wineous, slightly sweet but very balanced flavor with a hint of mushrooms. Flavor hides the ABV completely. Quite full-bodied, smooth, warming, slicky and slightly sugary palate with a bit foamy carbonation. An excellent, very well-balanced and tasty brew. Makes a very nice dessert with or without chocolate.
Bottle at dougshoemakers, dark amber/brown, nice creamy beige head, nice lacing, smells fruity and alcohol, taste of chocolate, cola, and alcohol.

75 cl bottle, bbe 15th Dec 06. Dark and dense appearance, with a head that doesnt quite fit into the picture. Orange zest, sticky malt and alcohol in the aroma. Porto, wood, orange in the bitter flavour which is drier than expected. Just a bit too sharp/acidic on the tongue. And it really goes well with chocolate, it enhances its flavour!

Bottled: Burgundy coloured. Brown fluffy head. Fruity, sweet and very chocolatish aroma. Light alcohol, some spices, fruit and the chocolate again dominates the flavour. Ends on a dry light alcoholdense note. Overall the alcohol is very well hidden. First beer of 2005 for me. It had all I could ask for.

Respectable looking ale, nice set of colours, and creamy head. Refreshing nose, full of flavours. Medium bodied ale, with some fruity undertones, plenty of warming alcohol and black chocolate. Sound and looks better on paper than really is.

Ruby-brown colour with a tan head. Sweet aroma of chocolate and cherries with some yeasty notes. Mild & bitter chocolate malt flavour with a warm and slightly spiced finish. Quite nice. [Toronto Christmas Party 04]

Cloudy dark brown w/ some yeast suspension. Rocky, light brown foam. Sweet, chocolaty aroma w/ a light yeastiness & some grassy hops. Medium, carbonated feel. Sweet, chocolaty, yeasty, mildly fruity flavour w/ notes of vinous wood. Warm, peppery finish.

Deep and dark brown, lighter brown head. Some cherry in the aroma along with some yeast and a good dose of malt. Sharp, dry flavor, raisin, yeast, malt. Medium to full bodied, pretty dry. I liked a lot. Thanks mr_kimchee.
Bottle provided at DougShoemakers.  Nice brown/chocolate color.  Aroma is like a cola.  Bits of fruit.  Yeasty.

Yeasty belgium, with black chocalate apearance. Some roast, sugary, bittersweet. Wood, black cherry notes,odd nuts and cocoa. Complex flavour but medium mouthfeel. For end of meal/dessert. Hugh carbonation and noticeable high alcohol. Different, worth having once.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2009 Bottle Black body.  Brown, creamy head, mostly diminishing.  Fair lace.  Toffee, liquor, grape, raisin aroma.  Lightly bitter, lightly sweet initial flavour.  Moderately bitter finish.  Heavy bodied.  Fizzy carbonation.

dark brown colour, creamy head, bready with banana and menthol notes, lot of carbonation, medium-bodied, dry and very bitter, the finish is very dry with a big alcohol kick at the end - thanks to fiulijn for sharing it
Sour cherry nose.  Sour & alcoholic lemon/lime.  Lots of warming alcohol.  Overly dry finish.

Well, calling it Dark Chocolate kind of ruined it for me right off the bat, as it set the stage for a sweet malty chocolatey beer, and that’s not what I got at all. Dark ruby brown body wiht a good sized beige head. Aroma is yeasty with a touch of sourness. Malty with a dry bitter finish. Decent palate, fairly effervescent.
Slightly citrus and barnyard on the nose, slight chocolate/ citrus finish w/ horseblanket on tongue.  Major effervesence and a rich color w/ really good head and minor lacing.

Pours a tall frothy light tan head on a dark brown body. Nice fruity aroma with malt notes. Sweet, full and complex. Flavor is also mostly sweet with a good bitterness behind. Malt and fruit with a roasted tone and notes of hop and spices. Sharp taste but still a soft mouthfull. Warming from the alcohol. A very well balanced and tasty beer!

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2005 Dark burgundy color.  Small, compacted, light mocha colored head.  Lightly aromatic, strange, funky aroma with dark, roasty tones.  Hazelnut flavors abound with light chestnut flavors along with roasty and toasted tones and a touch of raisins.  Well hidden alcohol and nice mouthfeel.

Celebration November 2004 at CapFlus place. Dark brown in colour with a long lasting head.  Aroma was yeasty, some chocolate, malt, slight sourness, cherries and grapes.  Flavour was yeasty, musty, malty, some dark chocolate, slight sweetness.  Large body, high carbonation, alcohol is not noticable.  Finishes with a light alcohol warmth.  Beautiful beer, thanks for bringing this muzzlehatch.

Let me first say the label looks fantastic, very classy. Dark coloured, lasting head. Malty, spicy and yeasty aroma, some alcohol. Dry malty flavour. Well brewed, but nevertheless none of these brut beers could really impress me so far. And its pretty damn expensive.

bottled 750ml. 2003. Dark brown with massive tan head. Chocolate and yeast smell. Medium bodied Not much chocolate taste. Well carbonated with a nice bitterness through out. Hides the alcohol content well. Smooth. multiple tastings. a very nice beer.

This brew pours with a cloudy, dark amber body topped by a thick, fizzy head with some lacing.  The aroma is slightly sour and vinious with a slight barnyard and a touch of alcohol.  Nice.  The flavor is slightly sweet yet slightly sour with a touch of barnyard and a touch of sourness.  A nice chocolate flavor shows through after a few tastes.  Meidum bodied, smooth and a touch dry.
Brown dark appearance. Choccolate, sweet, prune finish. A really great beer for a dessert. Elegant well-balanced beer. Velvety finish. Thanks to www.belgiskbryg.dk for the sample.

Wow - this was an extra from beandip, so kudos to her, in a deal with muzzlehatch, so thanks to Barry for bringing this one and sharing it with CapFlu, tiggmtl, radiomgb, Rastacouere and DumDum in Ottawa. 2003 Reserve bottle. Had this not been the second-last bottle in a long line of sampled beers I might have had the palate to better appreciate this one. As it was my tongue still seemed to discern its quality. Great aromas of black/sour cherry, malt and hop, chocolate and then some barnyard gueuziness too. Nice. Big head atop a cloudy brown body. Sweet malts are offset slightly with the bitter chocolate until it becomes a touch medicinally alcoholic. I think the wonderful tingling mouthfeel actually woke my mouth up a little, and I would definitely want this one again with fresher senses.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2005 Barnyard, pit fruit - notably cherries, horse-blanket, a light cinammon spiciness and of course, bittersweet, dark chocolate all intermingle in the wonderfully complex aroma. Solid-looking, opaque brown with thin but lasting, tan head. Perfume-like, saffron, tart, bitter chocolate flavour is initially malt dominated but a strong balancing bitterness emerges to counterpoint nicely. Touches of alcohol waft through the presentation without ever being dominant, though definitely warming. Crunchy mouthfeel - strong carbonation, fine-bubbled, engaging. More please! Bottle enjoyed with beerhugger, CapFlu, DumDum, muzzlehatch, radiomgb and Rastacouere.

750 ml bottle shared in Ottawa with diverse Ottavians and Montrealites:  Rastacouere, tiggmtl, beerhugger, CapFlu, DumDum, radiomgb).  Thick, luscious brown cola body, huge lasting head...big spicy nose full of sour cherries, farminess and some lovely dark chocolate...thick yet nimble body, with a slightly high carbonation level...complex sour chocolate-blueberry-cherry flavors, stinging medicinal alcohol on the finish, Jagermeister and champagne...truly wonderful, an exceptional treat courtesy of the most marvellous Beandip!

26oz: Dark chocolate brown, superb beige head is eternally lasting, foamy, full of subtle lacing. Enormous chocolate malt aroma, predictably tart, yet somehow, they managed to find a fit between this and saison-like haystack scents. I found the balance to be remarkable for such an experiment, delicate herbal and flowery undertones together add tremendous depth. Rich bitter/tart chocolate, actually this may be tarter than it appears, yet I didnt find any annoyance in the marriage with the roastiness. No trace of alcohol in the aroma, remarkable feature by itself, but in such a complex blend, you dont get to spend much time thinking about that. Add to this a killer expanding in bubbles incredibly smooth foamy mouthfeel and you know where your 25$ went. I still think I prefer the regular Brut, but then again, I tend to prefer blonde Belgians to darker ones. I can recognize a killer recipe though and this one gave me a hard time to find places to give less than perfect scores! Astonishingly unique. A sipper that you couldnt drink too much of while being an incarnation of greatness! de Landtsheer can brew people, my rating may be a mess, but take that for granted. Cheers to my pal muzzlehatch for this.

(22oz bottle) Never-never ending head with an opaque body. Nose of a cherry gueuze merged with a belgian strong and seep malt. Great chalkiness in the malt and the sour undertones are lovely. A tad medicinal... but greatly different from everything else in style.
Bottle @ Akkurat, StockholmVery lively. Unusually hoppy for a Belgian beer. Spicy and a hint of rubber. The alcohol content is well consealed.
Bottled. Dark brown, very lively. Chocolatey, sweet nose. Almondy and salty with grassy hops and notes of banana and yeast. Elegant soft mouthfeel. Lightly vinous. Dry finish.
Dark brown body with a frothy off white head. Woody aroma, almost lambic like, some dark fruits and malts. Very woody flavor, very refreshing. Very nice one.
Brown color with a small beige head. The taste is a sharp sweetness with a balanced yet dominant spicy pattern.

Very intens dark brown beer with an acajou red glow and almost no head. It has a warm and powerfull nose with hints of dates, dried figs, dried apricots, expresso coffee and ahorn sirup. This blockbusterbeer has a dens mouthfeeling with hints of Irish coffee and old Tréffin candys ( Butter caramels with coffee taste.) In the afthertaste you can notice a touch of black bitter chocolate. Overpowering beer that lacks some frechness in the end. Heavy stuff.
Sampled in a beer tasting at Plan B, Copenhagen. Magnificent head on a fine brown colour. Dark fruits, malts and chocolate. Alcohol is noticeable. Great with foods and chocolate (I presume).

Dark brown, with a long lasting tan head. Aromas include hops, dark fruit, malt, and some chocolate. Flavor is dark fruit, some coffee, some chocolate that start on the sweet side, but ends dry.  The aftertaste has some grape flavor. Very complex. Thanks to BeanDip for this one.

8/28/04.  Poured out of 750 mL bottle, sampled at Dr. Bill and Steinys 8th Annual 12-Hour Beer Festival in Orange, CA 8/28/04.  Pours a moderately dark brown, somewhat like a porter.  But excellent lacing from a tan head that fights and kicks to stay alive.  Nose has faint unsweetened chocolate and dried dark fruit hints.  Flavor gives off a bit of a sharply bitter, drying sensation.  Quite a surprising chocolate beer, in that theres really not a whole lot of chocolate.  But I bet it would go excellently WITH chocolate, as it sort of posits an apparition of a cocoa presence.  Some big wood evident, and the dry yet round, full mouthfeel is very lovely.  Damn good.

Thanks to fattyre for bringing this to the Georgia 14% gathering!
Theres a large, light Mocha colored head on this beer that sits on a dark amber colored base. 
Light malt aroma and the aroma and flavor of old apples. Tha palate is oily and alcoholic with a slightly sour finish. 
No chocolate anywhere.

The dark reddish brown body is topped by an appropriate light tan head. The aroma has a good bit of fruitiness and a little spice, but the chocolate, while there, really isnt there enough to justify the American name for this beer. This one seemed a little lacking compared to beers that came before and after it at the tasting. Im wondering if our bottle just wasnt as good as the bottles some of the other raters here have had.

Oh here this beer is! What a scavenger hunt to locate this one in the database. Reddish brown apperance. The aroma was very sweet consisting mostly of chocolate. The taste was a sweet and sour combo of chocolate, sour grapes, and some bitter coffee. This one wasnt great but good nonetheless.

Comes off fairly piney up front.  Some chocolate in the aroma.  Deep red-brown body.  Moderately sweet, lightly bitter flavor becomes a lightly sweet, moderately bitter, moderately acidic.  Medium body, watery texture, average carbonation.

Brown, nice head. Woodsy, piney earthy aroma. Spicy and earthy, with notes of black pepper and I dont know, maybe even mushroom? Some fruits - cherry, probably.  But wheres the choclate flavor? Huh? Huh?

Pours a clear brown with a thick light tan head.  Sweet and sour candi sugar aroma.  Starts slightly sour and bittersweet with a smooth malty thickness.  Not particulary chocolatey or roasty as the name might imply, but a nicely rounded and smooth Belgian ale.  Thanks to fattyre for bringing this to the Georgia 14% gathering!

Pours a hazy brownish amber, with some very nice head retention.  Spicy brown sugar aroma, vinegarish and sour at times, and when it warms you can really taste the alchohol, and a spicy brown sugar sweetness.  Unfortunately the alchohol becomes too much for this one in the finish it is just way too present.

Aroma is cherry, orange and chocolat. Red/brown color, beige head, very nice lace. Sweet, light bitter, wine, blackberries, coffee, quite complex, little sticky. Had a bottle which Black Chocolat on the label and 12% ABV. Why are so many breweries inconsistent with the ABV on the labels? This one beats the Brut Reserve by the way, especially in complexity.
Dark brown colour. Some malt and chocolate notes. Slightly alcoholic. Cocoa, strong, spicy. Quite interesting and special dry spicyness. Sparkling texture.
Brown coloured. The dark chocolate notes get along well with the dark fruits. The alcohol is noticeable. Dry finish.

Dark and murky. Huge rocky, pillowy tan head. Aroma is wonderful - powdery, flowery, cedar, chocolate, touch of citrus, sour, dark fruits, touch of peppery spice. Dries out on finish. Texture is rich and full and lingering. This so powdery - I love it. Touch of alcohol. Outstanding. The warmer this gets the better it is.
Deep brown color, medium brown head. Aroma of a bakers chocolate mixed with a grassy hops flavor and brown sugar.  Mouthfeel is slightly tart.  Moderately dry finish, thanks TAR for a great beer.

Beautiful, unique, complex. Subtle chocolate harmony. Dark russet color -- the perfect belgian chocolate hue. Belgian yeastiness and vinous esters infused with chocolate malt. Not many hoppy or bitter notes. Strong, raisiny, creamy and cake-like finish stands out amid the intense alcohol. Decadent and a true special-occasion brew.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 Rich auburn. Thick, lasting, large-bubbled, beige head. Lavish aroma of flowers, soft peachy esters, and perfume. Restrained brett character, herbal hops, butter rum, and firm malts. Extremely bright and vibrant. Fluffy and expansive, yet slightly pricklier than it is creamy on the tongue. Numbing alcohol underpins the zesty brett character and warms the innards. Harmonious flash of sweet malts and dry chocolate complement the  tight, toasty esters and bright tropical fruit display. Chocolate becomes creamier and more evident, midway, amid the soft peach esters and subtle chalky yeast tones. Gobs of underlying glazed, bready malt sweetness plays superbly with the understated chocolate and perfumey brett. Creamy chocolate texture coats the back of the palate before the extremely clean alcohol dries out the finish and highlights the subtle, yet well-defined brett note. Delayed fruity esters are sprinkled with eclaire pastry, butter rum, vanilla, and flowers, as the alcohol continues to warm the soul after the swallow. Remarkably composed throughout this humdinger of a brew. Stellar dessert brew, aperitif, or late evening sipper all by itself. How they crammed so may subtleties in such a huge beer is befuddling. Just as extravagant as their Brut Reserve.
